a: <entryFree id="n0" type="main" key="A1" n="I"><orth extent="full" lang="la">A</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">a</orth>, <itype>indecl.</itype> <gen>n.</gen> (sometimes joined with <sense id="n0.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">littera</hi>), the first letter of the Latin alphabet, corresponding to the a, <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign> of the other Indo-. European languages: <cit><quote lang="la">A primum est: hinc incipiam, et quae nomina ab hoc sunt, Lucil. ap. Terent. Scaur. p. 2255 P.: sus rostro si humi A litteram impresserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:13:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 13, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in A quidem atque S litteras exire temere masculina Graeca nomina recto casu patiebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:61" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 61</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n0.1" n="II" level="1">The sound of the A is <hi rend="ital">short</hi> or <hi rend="ital">long</hi> in every part of the word; as, ăb, păter, ită; ā, māter, frustrā. During a short period (between about 620 and 670 A. U. C. = from 134 to 84 B.C.) <hi rend="ital">long a</hi> was written <hi rend="ital">aa</hi>, probably first by the poet L. Attius, in the manner of the Oscan language; so we find in Latin inscriptions: AA. CETEREIS (i.e.a ceteris), CALAASI, FAATO, HAACE, MAARCIVM, PAAPVS, PAASTORES, VAARVS; and in Greek writing, MAAPKO<foreign lang="greek">*y</foreign> <foreign lang="greek">*y</foreign>IO<foreign lang="greek">*s</foreign> MAAPKEAAO<foreign lang="greek">*s</foreign>, KOINTON MAAPKION (like Osc. aasas = Lat. āra, Osc. Paapi = Lat. Pāpius, Osc. Paakul = Lat. Pāculus, Pācullus, Pācuvius, etc.), v. Ritschl, Monum. Epigr. p. 28 sq., and cf. Mommsen, Unterital. Dialekte, p. 210 sq. (The Umbrian language has gone a step farther, and written <hi rend="ital">long a</hi> by <hi rend="ital">aha</hi>, as Aharna, Naharcom, trahaf, etc.; cf. Aufrecht and Kirchhoff, Umbrische Sprachdenkm. p. 76 sq.) Vid. also the letters E and U.</sense><sense id="n0.2" n="III" level="1">In etymological and grammatical formation of words, <hi rend="ital">short a</hi> very often (sometimes also <hi rend="ital">long a</hi>) is changed into other vowels.</sense><sense id="n0.3" n="A" level="2"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed, </sense><sense id="n0.4" n="1" level="3">, into <hi rend="ital">long a</hi>—</sense><sense id="n0.5" n="a" level="4">In consequence of the suppression of the following consonants at the end or in the middle of the word: ŭb, <hi rend="ital">ā;</hi> vădis, <hi rend="ital">vūs;</hi> ăg-, ăg-men, <hi rend="ital">exāmen;</hi> tăg-, <hi rend="ital">contūmino;</hi> căd-, <hi rend="ital">cāsus</hi>. Hence also in the <hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi> of the first decl., and in the particles derived from it. in consequence of the suppression of the original ablat. end. -<hi rend="ital">d</hi>: PRAEDAD (Col. Rostr.), <hi rend="ital">praedā;</hi> SENTENTIAD (S. C. de Bacch.), <hi rend="ital">sententiā;</hi> EXTBAD (ib.), <hi rend="ital">extrā;</hi> SVPRAD (ib.), <hi rend="ital">suprā</hi>. —Hence,</sense><sense id="n0.6" n="b" level="4">In perfect forms: scăb-o, <hi rend="ital">scābi;</hi> căveo, <hi rend="ital">cūvi;</hi> făv-eo, <hi rend="ital">fāvi;</hi> păv-eo, <hi rend="ital">pāvi</hi> (for scăbui, căvui, făvui, păvui).</sense><sense id="n0.7" n="c" level="4">In other forms: ăgo, <hi rend="ital">ambūges;</hi> păc-, păc-iscor, <hi rend="ital">pâcis</hi> (pâx); săg-ax, <hi rend="ital">sūgus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sāga;</hi> măc-er, <hi rend="ital">mâcero;</hi> făg- (<foreign lang="greek">fagei=n</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">fūgus</hi>. (Contrary to analogy, <hi rend="ital">ă</hi> remains short in dănunt, from dă-in-unt, V. Ritschl, l.l.p. 17.)</sense><sense id="n0.8" n="2" level="3"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed into é or ē—</sense><sense id="n0.9" n="a" level="4">Into é. (a) Most frequently in the second part of compounds, particularly <hi rend="ital">before two consonants</hi>: facio, <hi rend="ital">confectus;</hi> jacio, <hi rend="ital">conjectus;</hi> rapio, <hi rend="ital">dereptus;</hi> dăm-, damno, <hi rend="ital">condemno;</hi> fāl-, fallo, <hi rend="ital">fefelli;</hi> măn-, mando, <hi rend="ital">commendo;</hi> scando, <hi rend="ital">ascendo;</hi> ăp-, aptus, <hi rend="ital">ineptus;</hi> ăr-, ars, <hi rend="ital">iners</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sollers;</hi> ăn-, annus, <hi rend="ital">perennis;</hi> căpio, <hi rend="ital">auceps;</hi> căput, <hi rend="ital">triceps;</hi> ăgo, <hi rend="ital">remex;</hi> jăcio, <hi rend="ital">objex</hi>. And thus in Plautus, according to the best MSS., <hi rend="ital">dispenno, dispessus</hi> from pando, <hi rend="ital">compectus</hi> from compăciscor, <hi rend="ital">anteceptus</hi> from capio (on the other hand, in Vergil, according to the best MS., <hi rend="ital">aspurgo, attractare, deiractare,</hi> kept their <hi rend="ital">a</hi> unchanged).</sense><sense id="n0.10" n="(b)" level="5">Sometimes <hi rend="ital">ă</hi> is changed into <hi rend="ital">ĕ</hi> also before <hi rend="ital">one consonant</hi> (but in this case it is usually changed into <hi rend="ital">ĭ;</hi> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>, 3. a. <hi rend="ital">a</hi>.): grădior, <hi rend="ital">ingrĕdior;</hi> pătior, <hi rend="ital">perpĕtior;</hi> părio, <hi rend="ital">repĕrio;</hi> păro, <hi rend="ital">vitupĕro;</hi> ăp-, <hi rend="ital">coepi</hi> (i. e. co-ŭpi); căno, <hi rend="ital">tubicĕn, tibicĕn;</hi> in the reduplicated <hi rend="ital">carcĕr</hi> (from carcar) <hi rend="ital">farfŏrus</hi> (written also farfārus); and so, according to <cb n="A" /> the better MSS., <hi rend="ital">aequipĕro</hi> from păro, and <hi rend="ital">defĕtigo</hi> from fătigo.</sense><sense id="n0.11" n="(g)" level="5">In words taken from the Greek: <foreign lang="greek">ta/lanton</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">talŏntum;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">fa/lara</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">phalŏrae;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">si/saron</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">sisŏr</hi> (but, according to the best MSS., <hi rend="ital">cumŭra</hi> from <foreign lang="greek">kama/ra</foreign>, not <hi rend="ital">camŏra</hi>).</sense><sense id="n0.12" n="b" level="4"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed to ē in some perfect forms: ăgo, <hi rend="ital">ēgi;</hi> fūcio, <hi rend="ital">féci;</hi> jăci, <hi rend="ital">jĕci;</hi> frag-, frango, <hi rend="ital">frēgi;</hi> căpio, cēpi, and păg-, pango, <hi rend="ital">pēgi</hi> (together with <hi rend="ital">pepĭgi</hi> and <hi rend="ital">panxi</hi>, v. pango).</sense><sense id="n0.13" n="3" level="3"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed to ĭ, <orth extent="full" lang="la">a</orth> (most frequently in the second part of compounds) </sense><sense id="n0.14" n="(a)" level="5"> before <hi rend="ital">one consonant</hi>: ăgo, <hi rend="ital">abĭgo;</hi> făcio, <hi rend="ital">confĭcio;</hi> cădo, <hi rend="ital">concĭdo;</hi> sălio, <hi rend="ital">assĭlio;</hi> răpio, <hi rend="ital">abrĭpio;</hi> păter, <hi rend="ital">Juppĭter</hi> (in Umbrian lang. unchanged, Jupater), <hi rend="ital">Marspĭter; Diespĭter, Opĭter;</hi> rătus, <hi rend="ital">irrĭtus;</hi> ămicus, <hi rend="ital">inìmicus</hi> (but <hi rend="ital">ŭ</hi> remains unchanged in <hi rend="ital">adŭmo, impătiens,</hi> and in some compounds of a later period of Roman literature, as <hi rend="ital">praejacio, calefacio,</hi> etc.). —</sense><sense id="n0.15" n="(b)" level="5"> Sometimes also before <hi rend="ital">two consonants</hi> (where it is usually changed into <hi rend="ital">ĕ;</hi> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">supra</ref></xr>, 2. <foreign lang="greek">a. b.</foreign>): tăg-, tango, <hi rend="ital">contingo;</hi> păg-, pango, <hi rend="ital">compingo</hi> (unchanged in some compounds, as <hi rend="ital">peragro, desacro, depango, obcanto</hi>, etc.).</sense><sense id="n0.16" n="b" level="4"><hi rend="ital">ă</hi> is changed into ĭ in the reduplicated perfect forms: <hi rend="ital">cădo, cecĭdi; căno, cecĭni;</hi> tăg-, tango, <hi rend="ital">tetĭgi;</hi> păg-, pango, <hi rend="ital">pepĭgi</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.17" n="c" level="4">Likewise in some roots which have <hi rend="ital">ă</hi>: păg-, <hi rend="ital">pignus;</hi> străg- (strangulo, <foreign lang="greek">stra/ggw</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">stringo</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.18" n="d" level="4">In words taken from the Greek: <foreign lang="greek">mhxanh/</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">machĭna;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">pata/nh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">patĭna;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">buka/nh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">bucĭna;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">truta/nh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">trutĭna;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">balanei=on</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">balĭneum;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">*kata/na</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Catĭna</hi> (written also Catana); ‘<foreign lang="greek">*akra/gas</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Agrĭgentum</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.19" n="4" level="3"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed into <hi rend="ital">short</hi> or <hi rend="ital">long o</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.20" n="a" level="4">Into <hi rend="ital">ŏ</hi>: scăbo, <hi rend="ital">scobs;</hi> păr, pars, <hi rend="ital">portio;</hi> dăm-, <hi rend="ital">dŏmo;</hi> Fabii, <hi rend="ital">Fŏvii</hi> (v. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=87" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 87</bibl>); <foreign lang="greek">ma/rmaron</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">marmŏr;</hi> Mars, redupl. Marmar, <hi rend="ital">Marmor</hi> (Carm. Fratr. Arv.).</sense><sense id="n0.21" n="b" level="4">Into <hi rend="ital">ō</hi>: dă-, dōnum, dōs; ăc-, ăcuo, ōcior (v. this art.).</sense><sense id="n0.22" n="5" level="3"><hi rend="ital">Short a</hi> is changed into <hi rend="ital">ŭ</hi>—</sense><sense id="n0.23" n="a" level="4">In the second part of compounds, particularly before <hi rend="ital">l, p</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">b</hi>: calco, <hi rend="ital">inculco;</hi> salsus, <hi rend="ital">insulsus;</hi> salto, <hi rend="ital">exsulto;</hi> capio, <hi rend="ital">occŭpo;</hi> răpio, <hi rend="ital">surrupio</hi> and <hi rend="ital">surruptus</hi> (also written surripio and surreptus); tăberna, <hi rend="ital">contŭbernium;</hi> —before other consonants: quătio, <hi rend="ital">conoŭtio;</hi> as, <hi rend="ital">decussis;</hi> Mars, <hi rend="ital">Mamŭrius, Mamŭralia;</hi> and once also <hi rend="ital">condumnari</hi> (Tab. Bant. lin. 8, immediately followed by <hi rend="ital">condemnatus</hi>, v. Klenze, Philol. Abhandl. tab. I., and Mommsen, Unterital. Dial. p. 149).</sense><sense id="n0.24" n="b" level="4">In words of Greek origin: ‘<foreign lang="greek">*eka/bh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Hecŭba;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">skuta/lh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">scutŭla;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">kraipa/lh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">crapŭla;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">pa/ssalos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">pessŭlus;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">a=flaston</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">aplustre;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">qri/ambos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">triumphus</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.25" n="c" level="4"><hi rend="ital">ă</hi> is perhaps changed into <hi rend="ital">ŭ</hi> in ulciscor, compared with alc-, <foreign lang="greek">u)le/cw</foreign> (arc-, arceo).</sense><sense id="n0.26" n="B" level="2"><hi rend="ital">Long a</hi> is sometimes changed into <hi rend="ital">ē</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ō</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.27" n="1" level="3">Into <hi rend="ital">é</hi>: hālo, <hi rend="ital">anhélo;</hi> fās-, <hi rend="ital">féstus, profēstus;</hi> nām, <hi rend="ital">némpe</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.28" n="2" level="3">Into <hi rend="ital">ō</hi>: gnā-, gnārus, ignārus, <hi rend="ital">ignōro</hi>. (But in general <hi rend="ital">long a</hi> remains unchanged in composition: lābor, <hi rend="ital">delūbor;</hi> gnàvus, <hi rend="ital">ignūnus;</hi> fàma, <hi rend="ital">infūmis</hi>.)</sense><sense id="n0.29" n="IV" level="1">Contrary to the mode of changing Greek <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign> into Latin <hi rend="ital">e, i, o, u</hi> (v. supra), Latin <hi rend="ital">a</hi> has sometimes taken the place of other Greek vowels in words borrowed from the Greek, as: <foreign lang="greek">lo/gxh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">lancea;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">ku/lic</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">călix;</hi> <foreign lang="greek">*ganumho)hs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Caiāmitus</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.30" n="V" level="1">The repugnance of the Latin Language <cb n="A" /> to the Greek combined vowels <foreign lang="greek">ao</foreign> has caused the translocation of them in <hi rend="ital">Alumento</hi> for <foreign lang="greek">*daome/o\wn</foreign> (Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=18" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 18</bibl> Müll.).— Greek <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign> is suppressed in <hi rend="ital">Hercules</hi> from ‘<foreign lang="greek">*hraklh=s</foreign> (probably in consequence of the inserted <hi rend="ital">u;</hi> in late Latin we find <hi rend="ital">Heracla</hi> and <hi rend="ital">Heracula</hi>, cf. Ritschl, in Rhein. Mus. Neue Folge, vol. 12, p. 108).</sense><sense id="n0.31" n="VI" level="1">Latin <hi rend="ital">ă</hi> was early combined with the vowels <hi rend="ital">i</hi> and <hi rend="ital">u</hi>, forming the diphthongs <hi rend="ital">ai</hi> and <hi rend="ital">au;</hi> by changing the <hi rend="ital">i</hi> into <hi rend="ital">e</hi>, the diphthong <hi rend="ital">ai</hi> soon became <hi rend="ital">ae</hi>. So we find in the oldest inscriptions: AIDE, AIDLLIS, AIQVOM, GNAIVOD, HAICE, DVELONAI, TABELAI, DATAI, etc., which soon gave place to aedem, aedilis, aequom, Gnaeo, haec, Bellonae, tabellae, datae, etc. (the Col. Rostr. has PRAESENTE, PRAEDAD, and the S. C. de Bacch. AEDEM. The triphthong <hi rend="ital">aei</hi>, found in CONQVAEISIVEI (?), is very rare; Miliar. Popil. lin. 11, v. Ritschl, l. l. p. 21). In some poets the old gen. sing. of the first decl. (-<hi rend="ital">ai</hi>) is preserved, but is dissyllabic, <hi rend="ital">āī</hi>. So in Ennius: <hi rend="ital">Albūī Longūī, terrūī frugiferāī, frondosāī, lunāī, viāī;</hi> in Vergil: <hi rend="ital">aulāī, aurāī, aquāī, pictāī;</hi> in Ausonius: <hi rend="ital">herāī</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.32" n="B" level="2"><hi rend="ital">ue</hi> as well as <hi rend="ital">au</hi> are changed into other vowels.</sense><sense id="n0.33" n="1" level="3">The sound of <hi rend="ital">ae, e</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">oe</hi> being very similar, these vowels are often interchanged in the best MSS., So we find <hi rend="ital">caerimonia</hi> and <hi rend="ital">cerimonia, caepa</hi> and <hi rend="ital">cēpa, saeoulum</hi> and <hi rend="ital">séculum; scaena</hi> and <hi rend="ital">scēna; caelum</hi> and <hi rend="ital">coelum, haedus</hi> and <hi rend="ital">hoedus, macstus</hi> and <hi rend="ital">moestus; cena, coena</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">caena</hi>, etc.</sense><sense id="n0.34" n="2" level="3">In composition and reduplications <hi rend="ital">ae</hi> becomes <hi rend="ital">í</hi>: aequus, <hi rend="ital">iníquus;</hi> quaero, <hi rend="ital">inquíro;</hi> laedo, <hi rend="ital">illído;</hi> taedet, <hi rend="ital">pertisum</hi> (noticed by Cic.); aestumo, <hi rend="ital">exístumo;</hi> cuedo, <hi rend="ital">cecídi, concído, homicida</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.35" n="3" level="3"><hi rend="ital">ae</hi> is also changed into <hi rend="ital">í</hi> in a Latinized word of Greek origin: <foreign lang="greek">*)axaio/s （*)axaivo/s）</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Achíous</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.36" n="4" level="3">The diphthong <hi rend="ital">au</hi> is often changed to <hi rend="ital">ó</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ú</hi> (the latter particularly in compounds): <hi rend="ital">caudex, códex; Claudius, Clodius; lautus, lotus; plaustrum, plōstrum; plaudo, plōdo, explōdo; paululum, pōlulum; faux, suffōco; si audes</hi> (acc. to Cic. or acc. to others, si audies), <hi rend="ital">sódes</hi>, etc.; <hi rend="ital">claudo, inclūdo; causa, accūso</hi>. Hence in some words a regular gradation of <hi rend="ital">au, o, u</hi> is found: <hi rend="ital">claudo, clōdicare</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clúdo; raudus, ródus, rúdus; caupo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cópa, cūpa; naugae, nōgae</hi> (both forms in the MSS. of Plautus), <hi rend="ital">nūgae; fraustra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frode, frude</hi> (in MSS. of Vergil); cf. Ritschl, in Wintercatalog 1854-55, and O. Ribbeck, in Jahn's Neue Jahrb. vol. 77, p. 181 sq.—The change of <hi rend="ital">au</hi> into <hi rend="ital">oē</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ō</hi> appears only in audio, (oboedio) <hi rend="ital">obēdio</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.37" n="5" level="3"><hi rend="ital">Au</hi> sometimes takes the place of <hi rend="ital">av-: faveo, fautum, favitor, fautor; navis, navita, nauta;</hi> avis, <hi rend="ital">auceps, auspex</hi>. So Latin <hi rend="ital">aut</hi> corresponds to Sanscr. <hi rend="ital">avo</hi>. (whence -<hi rend="ital">vā</hi>, Lat. -<hi rend="ital">ve</hi>), Osc. <hi rend="ital">avti</hi>, Umbr. <hi rend="ital">ute, ote;</hi> and so the Lat. preposition <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, through <hi rend="ital">av</hi>, becomes <hi rend="ital">au</hi> in the words <hi rend="ital">aufero</hi> and <hi rend="ital">aufugio</hi> (prop. av-fero, av-fugio, for ab-fero, ab-fugio). Vid. the art. ab <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense><sense id="n0.38" n="VII" level="1">In primitive roots, which have their kindred forms in the sister-languages of the Latin, the original <hi rend="ital">a</hi>, still found in the Sanscrit, is in Latin either preserved or more frequently changed into other vowels.</sense><sense id="n0.39" n="A" level="2"><hi rend="ital">Original a</hi> preserved: Sanscr. <hi rend="ital">mātri</hi>, Lat. màter; S. <hi rend="ital">bhrātri</hi>, L. fràter; S. <hi rend="ital">nāsā</hi>, L. nàsus and nàris; S. <hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, L. aqua; S. <hi rend="ital">apa</hi>, L. ab; S. <hi rend="ital">nāma</hi>, L. năm; S. ćatur, <pb n="2" /> <cb n="AB" /> L. quattuor (in Greek changed: <foreign lang="greek">te(ttares</foreign>); S. <hi rend="ital">capūla</hi>, L. căput (in Greek changed: <foreign lang="greek">kefalh/</foreign>, etc.).</sense><sense id="n0.40" n="B" level="2"><hi rend="ital">Original a</hi> is changed into other Latin vowels—</sense><sense id="n0.41" n="1" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">e</hi>: S. <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, L. ed (ĕdo); S. <hi rend="ital">as</hi>, L. es (esse); S. <hi rend="ital">pat</hi>, L. pet (peto); S. <hi rend="ital">pād</hi>, L. pĕd (pès); S. <hi rend="ital">dant</hi>, L. dent (dens); S. <hi rend="ital">ǵan</hi>, L. gen (gigno); S. <hi rend="ital">mā</hi>, L. mè-tior; S. <hi rend="ital">saptan</hi>, L. septem; S. <hi rend="ital">daśan</hi>, L. decem; S. <hi rend="ital">śata</hi>, L. centum; S. <hi rend="ital">aham</hi>, L. ŏgo; S. <hi rend="ital">pāra</hi>, L. per; S. <hi rend="ital">paśu</hi>, L. pŏcus; S. <hi rend="ital">asva</hi>, L. ŏquus, etc.</sense><sense id="n0.42" n="2" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">i</hi>: S. <hi rend="ital">an-</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a-</hi> (neg. part.), L. in-: S. <hi rend="ital">ana</hi> (prep.), L. in; S. <hi rend="ital">antar</hi>, L. inter; S. <hi rend="ital">sama</hi>, L. similis; S. <hi rend="ital">agni</hi>, L. ignis; S. <hi rend="ital">abhra</hi>, L. imber; S. <hi rend="ital">panéa</hi>, L. quinque, etc.</sense><sense id="n0.43" n="3" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">o</hi>: S. <hi rend="ital">avi</hi>, L. ŏvi (ovis); S. <hi rend="ital">vać</hi>, L. vōc (voco); S. <hi rend="ital">pra</hi>, L. pro; S. <hi rend="ital">pā</hi>, L. po (pŏtum); S. <hi rend="ital">nāma</hi>, L. nōmen; S. <hi rend="ital">api</hi>, L. ŏb; S. <hi rend="ital">navan</hi>, L. nŏvem; S. <hi rend="ital">nava</hi>, L. nŏvus, etc.</sense><sense id="n0.44" n="4" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">u</hi>: S. <hi rend="ital">marmara</hi>, L. murmur.</sense><sense id="n0.45" n="5" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">ai</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ae</hi>: S. <hi rend="ital">prati</hi>, L. (prai) prae; S. <hi rend="ital">śaśpa</hi>, L. caespes.</sense><sense id="n0.46" n="6" level="3"> Into <hi rend="ital">different vowels</hi> in the different derivatives: S. <hi rend="ital">mā</hi>, L. mê-tior, mŏdus; S. <hi rend="ital">praó</hi>, L. prŏcor, prŏcus; S. <hi rend="ital">vah</hi>, L. vĕho, via.</sense><sense id="n0.47" n="C" level="2"> Sometimes the Latin has preserved the original <hi rend="ital">a</hi>, while even the Sanscrit has changed it: Lat. pa-, pater, Sanscr. <hi rend="ital">pd</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pitri</hi>.</sense><sense id="n0.48" n="2" level="3"> As an abbreviation A. usually denotes the praenomen <hi rend="ital">Aulus;</hi> A. A. = <hi rend="ital">Auli duo</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1530</bibl> (but A. A. = Aquae Aponi, <hi rend="ital">the modern Abano</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1643 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2620</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3011</bibl>). The three directors of the mint were designated by III. VIRI A. A. A. F. F. (i. e. auro, argento, aeri flando, feriundo), <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 569</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2242</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2379</bibl>; 3134 al.; <cit><quote lang="la">so also A. A. A.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3441</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 13 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>, and v. the art. Triumviri); A. D. A. <hi rend="ital">agris dandis adsignandis</hi>, and A. I. A. <hi rend="ital">agris judicandis adsignandis;</hi> A. O. <hi rend="ital">amico optimo;</hi> A. P. <hi rend="ital">a populo</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aediliciae potestatis;</hi> A. P. R. <hi rend="ital">aerario populi Romani</hi>. —Upon the voting tablets in judicial trials A. denoted <hi rend="ital">absoluo;</hi> hence A. is called <hi rend="ital">littera salutaris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 6, 15</bibl>; v. littera. In the Roman Comitia A. (=<hi rend="ital">antiquo</hi>) denoted the rejection of the point in question; v. antiquo. In Cicero's Tusculan Disputations the A. designated one of the disputants = <hi rend="ital">adulescens</hi> or <hi rend="ital">auditor</hi>, opp. to M. for <hi rend="ital">magister</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Marcus</hi> (Cicero); but it is to be remarked that the letters A and M do not occur in the best MSS. of this treatise; cf. edd. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:5:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 5, 9</bibl>.—In dates A. D. =<hi rend="ital">ante diem;</hi> v. ante; A. U. C. = <hi rend="ital">anno urbis conditae;</hi> A. P. R. C. <hi rend="ital">anno post Romam conditam</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n1" type="main" key="a2" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">a</orth>, <pos>prep.</pos>=ab, v. ab.</entryFree>
<entryFree id="n2" type="main" key="a_3" n="4"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos>=ah, v. ah.</entryFree>
aaron: <entryFree id="n3" type="main" key="A^a^ro_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăărōn</orth> (Ăārōn, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Psych. 884</bibl>), <itype>indecl.</itype> or <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <foreign /> <sense id="n3.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Aaron</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Moses</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">first high-priest of the Hebrews</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 4, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 25 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
ab: <entryFree id="n4" type="main" key="a^b"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb, ā</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">abs</orth>, <pos>prep.</pos> with <case>abl.</case> This IndoEuropean particle (Sanscr. apa or ava, Etr. av, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">u)po/</foreign>, Goth. af, Old Germ. aba, New Germ. ab, Engl. of, off) has in Latin the following forms: <sense id="n4.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">af</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> (av), <hi rend="ital">au-</hi>, ā, <hi rend="ital">ă; aps</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as-</hi>. The existence of the oldest form, <hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, is proved by the oldest and best MSS. analogous to the prep. apud, the Sanscr. api, and Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/</foreign>, and by the weakened form <hi rend="ital">af</hi>, which, by the rule of historical grammar and the nature of the Latin letter <hi rend="ital">f</hi>, can be derived only from <hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, not from <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>. The form <hi rend="ital">af</hi>, weakened from <hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, also very soon became obsolete. There are but five examples of it in inscriptions, at the end of the sixth and in the course of the seventh century B. C., viz.: <cit><quote lang="la">AF VOBEIS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3114</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">AF MVRO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 6601</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">AF CAPVA,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3308</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">AF SOLO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 589</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">AF LYCO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3036</bibl></cit> (<hi rend="ital">afuolunt</hi>=avolant, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl> Múll., is only a conjecture). In the time of Cicero this form was regarded as archaic, and only here and there used in account-books; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:47:158" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 47, 158</bibl> (where the correct reading is <hi rend="ital">af</hi>, not <hi rend="ital">abs</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>), and cf. Ritschl, Monum. Epigr. p. 7 sq.—The second form of this preposition, changed from <hi rend="ital">ap</hi>, was <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, which has become the principal form and the one most generally <cb n="AB" /> used through all periods—and indeed the only oue used before all vowels and <hi rend="ital">h;</hi> here and there also before some consonants, particularly <hi rend="ital">l</hi>, <hi rend="ital">n</hi>, <hi rend="ital">r</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">s;</hi> rarely before <hi rend="ital">c</hi>, <hi rend="ital">j</hi>, <hi rend="ital">d</hi>, <hi rend="ital">t;</hi> and almost never before the labials <hi rend="ital">p</hi>, <hi rend="ital">b</hi>, <hi rend="ital">f</hi>, <hi rend="ital">v</hi>, or before <hi rend="ital">m</hi>, such examples as <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> Massiliensibus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 35</bibl>, being of the most rare occurrence.—By changing the <hi rend="ital">b</hi> of <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> through <hi rend="ital">v</hi> into <hi rend="ital">u</hi>, the form <hi rend="ital">au</hi> originated, which was in use only in the two compounds <hi rend="ital">aufero</hi> and <hi rend="ital">aufugio</hi> for abfero, ab-fugio; <hi rend="ital">aufuisse</hi> for afuisse, in Cod. Medic. of <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 17</bibl>, is altogether unusual. Finally, by dropping the <hi rend="ital">b</hi> of <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, and lengthening the <hi rend="ital">a</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> was changed into <hi rend="ital">á</hi>, which form, together with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, predominated through all periods of the Latin language, and took its place before all consonants in the later years of Cicero, and after him almoet exclusively.—By dropping the <hi rend="ital">b</hi> without lengthening the <hi rend="ital">a</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> occurs in the form <hi rend="ital">ă-</hi> in the two compounds <hi rend="ital">ă-bîo</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ă-pĕrio</hi>, q. v.—On the other hand, instead of reducing <hi rend="ital">ap</hi> to <hi rend="ital">a</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ă</hi>, a strengthened collateral form, <hi rend="ital">aps</hi>, was made by adding to <hi rend="ital">ap</hi> the letter <hi rend="ital">s</hi> (also used in particles, as in <hi rend="ital">ex</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mox</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vix</hi>). From the first, <hi rend="ital">aps</hi> was used only before the letters <hi rend="ital">c</hi>, <hi rend="ital">q</hi>, <hi rend="ital">t</hi>, and was very soon changed into <hi rend="ital">abs</hi> (as <hi rend="ital">ap</hi> into <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">abs chorago,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 3, 79</bibl></cit> (159 Ritschl): <cit><quote lang="la">abs quivis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abs terra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 51</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in compounds: aps-cessero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 1, 24</bibl></cit> (625 R.); <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 2, 84</bibl> (710 R): abs-condo, abs-que, abs-tineo, etc. The use of <hi rend="ital">abs</hi> was confined almost exclusively to the combination <hi rend="ital">abs te</hi> during the whole ante-classic period, and with Cicero till about the year 700 A. U. C. (=B. C. 54). After that time Cicero evidently hesitates between <hi rend="ital">abs te</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a te</hi>, but during the last five or six years of his life <hi rend="ital">a te</hi> became predominant in all his writings, even in his letters; consequently <hi rend="ital">abs te</hi> appears but rarely in later authors, as in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:19:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 19, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:15:12" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 15, 12</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and who, perhaps, also used abs conscendentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:37:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 37, 2</bibl></cit>; v. Drakenb. ad. h. l. (Weissenb. <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>).—Finally <hi rend="ital">abs</hi>, in consequence of the following <hi rend="ital">p</hi>, lost its <hi rend="ital">b</hi>, and became <hi rend="ital">ds-</hi> in the three compounds <hi rend="ital">aspello</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as-porto</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">as-pernor</hi> (for asspernor); <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">these words</ref></xr>.—The late Lat. verb <hi rend="ital">abbrevio</hi> may stand for adbrevio, the <hi rend="ital">d</hi> of <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> being assimilated to the following <hi rend="ital">b</hi>.The fundamental signification of <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> is <hi rend="ital">departure from some fixed point</hi> (opp. to ad. which denotes motion to a point). </sense><sense id="n4.1" n="I" level="1"> In space, and, </sense><sense id="n4.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., in time and other relations, in which the idea of departure from some point, as from source and origin, is included; Engl. <hi rend="ital">from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">away from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">out of; down from; since</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after; by</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on</hi>, etc.</sense><sense id="n4.3" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, in space: ab classe ad urbem tendunt, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 495, 22</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 177 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar maturat ab urbe proficisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fuga ab urbe turpissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducite ab urbe domum, ducite Daphnim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 8, 68</bibl></cit>. Cicero himself gives the difference between <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ex</hi> thus: si qui mihi praesto fuerit cum armatis hominibus extra meum fundum et me introire prohibuerit, non <hi rend="ital">ex</hi> eo, sed <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> (<hi rend="ital">from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">away from</hi>) eo loco me dejecerit. ...Unde dejecti Galli? <hi rend="ital">A</hi> Capitolio. Unde, qui cum Graccho fucrunt? <hi rend="ital">Ex</hi> Capitolio, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:30:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 30, 87</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 408</bibl> P., and a similar distinction between <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in</hi> under ad.—Ellipt.: Diogenes Alexandro roganti, ut diceret, si quid opus esset: <hi rend="ital">Nunc quidem paululum</hi>, inquit, <hi rend="ital">a sole</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little out of the sun</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:32:92" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 32, 92</bibl>. —Often joined with usque: <cit><quote lang="la">illam (mulierem) usque a mari supero Romam proficisci,</quote> <trans><tr>all the way from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:68:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 68, 192</bibl></cit>; v. usque, I.—And with ad, to denote the space passed over: siderum genus ab ortu ad occasum commeant, <hi rend="ital">from</hi> ... <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 19 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>; cf. <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> ... <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">venti a laevo latere in dextrum, ut sol, ambiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 48, § 128</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.4" n="b" level="4"> Sometimes with names of cities and small islands, or with domus (instead of the usual <case>abl.</case>), partie., in militnry and nautieal language, to denote the marching of soldiers, the setting out of a flcet, or the departure of the inhabitants from some place: <cit><quote lang="la">oppidum ab Aenea fugiente a Trojā conditum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quemadmodum (Caesar) a Gergovia discederet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 43 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 80</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:82" default="NO" valid="yes">82</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:91" default="NO" valid="yes">91</bibl>; <cb n="AB" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:33:6 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 33, 6 al.</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab Arimino M. Antonium cum cohortibus quinque Arretium mittit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">protinus a Corfinio in Siciliam miserat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 25, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">profecti a domo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:33:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 33, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of setting sail: cum exercitus vestri numquam a Brundisio nisi hieme summā transmiserint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:12:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 12, 32</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 24</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">classe quā advecti ab domo fuerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:22:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 22, 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of citizens: interim ab Roma legatos venisse nuntiatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 9, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">legati ab Orico ad M. Valerium praetorem venerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:40:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 40, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.5" n="c" level="4"> Sometimes with names of persons or with pronouns: pestem abige a me, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 28, 89</bibl> (Trag. v. 50 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">Quasi ad adulescentem a patre ex Seleucia veniat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:3:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 3, 41</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">libertus a Fuflis cum litteris ad Hermippum venit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 20, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nigidium a Domitio Capuam venisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum a vobis discessero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa merces tibi defluat ab Jove Neptunoque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:28:29 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 28, 29 al.</bibl></cit> So often of a person instead of his house, lodging, etc.: videat forte hic te a patre aliquis exiens, <hi rend="ital">from the father</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">from his house</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 2, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">so a fratre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Pontio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab eā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 21</bibl></cit>; and so often: a me, a nobis, a se, etc., <hi rend="ital">from my</hi>, <hi rend="ital">our</hi>, <hi rend="ital">his house</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 5, 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:9:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 9, 1 al.</bibl></sense><sense id="n4.6" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, without the idea of motion. To designate separation or distance, with the verbs <hi rend="ital">abesse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distare</hi>, etc., and with the particles <hi rend="ital">longe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">procul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prope</hi>, etc. </sense><sense id="n4.7" n="1" level="3"> Of separation: <cit><quote lang="la">ego te afuisse tam diu a nobis dolui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abesse a domo paulisper maluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:18:section=39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 18, § 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum Brutus ab Romā aberat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 40:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 40, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">absint lacerti ab stabulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4.8" n="2" level="3"> Of distance: <cit><quote lang="la">quot milia fundus suus abesset ab urbe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 10, 28</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nos in castra properabamus, quae aberant bidui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">hic locus aequo fere spatio ab castris Ariovisti et Caesaris aberat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:43:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 43, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrae ab hujusce terrae, quam nos incolimus, continuatione distantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:66:164" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 66, 164</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non amplius pedum milibus duobus ab castris castra distabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:82:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 82, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. id. lb. 1, 3, 103.—With <hi rend="ital">adverbs</hi>: annos multos longinque ab domo bellum gerentes, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 402, 3</bibl> (Trag. v. 103 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum domus patris a foro longe abesset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 7, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui fontes a quibusdam praesidiis aberant longius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:49:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 49, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae procul erant a conspectu imperii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:32:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 32, 87</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">procul a castris hostes in collibus constiterunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:17:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 17, 1</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">tu procul a patria Alpinas nives vides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 46</bibl></cit> (procul often also with simple <case>abl.</case>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. procul): cum esset in Italia bellum tam prope a Sicilia, tamen in Sicilia non fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:2:section=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 2, § 6</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">tu apud socrum tuam prope a meis aedibus sedebas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:11:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 11, 26</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">tam prope ab domo detineri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:3:section=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 3, § 6</bibl></cit>.—So in Cæsar and Livy, with <hi rend="ital">numerals</hi> to designate the <hi rend="ital">measure of the distance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">onerariae naves, quae ex eo loco ab milibus passuum octo vento tenebatur,</quote> <trans><tr>eight miles distant</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:22:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 22, 4</bibl></cit>; and without mentioning the <hi rend="ital">terminus a quo</hi>: ad castra contenderunt, et ab milibus passunm minus duobus castra posuerunt, <hi rend="ital">less than two miles off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distant</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 3</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 5, 32</bibl>; 6, 7, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:20:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 20, 2</bibl> (for which: <cit><quote lang="la">duo milia fere et quingentos passus ab hoste posuerunt castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:38:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 38, 5</bibl></cit>). —</sense><sense id="n4.9" n="3" level="3"> To denote the side or direction from which an object is viewed in its local relations,=a parte, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: utrum hacin feriam an ab laevā latus? Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 3, 10</bibl> (Trag. v. 38 Vahl.); cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">picus et cornix ab laevā, corvos, parra ab dexterā consuadent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: clamore ab ea parte audito. <hi rend="ital">on this side</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:26:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 26, 4</bibl>: Gallia Celtica attingit ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, <hi rend="ital">on the side of the Sequani</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">their country</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pleraque Alpium ab Italiā sicut breviora ita arrectiora sunt,</quote> <trans><tr>on the Italian side</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:35:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 35, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non eadem diligentiā ab decumunā portā castra munita,</quote> <trans><tr>at the main entrance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 25 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">erat a septentrionibus collis,</quote> <trans><tr>on the north</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 83, 2</bibl></cit>; so, ab oriente, a meridie, ab occasu; a fronte, a latere, a tergo, etc. (v. these words).</sense><sense id="n4.10" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n4.11" n="A" level="2"> In time. </sense><sense id="n4.12" n="1" level="3"> From a <pb n="3" /> <cb n="AB" /> point of time, without reference to the period subsequently elapsed. <hi rend="ital">After</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Exul ab octava Marius bibit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:40" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1,40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulieres jam ab re divin[adot  ] adparebunt domi,</quote> <trans><tr>immediately after the sucrifice</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar ab decimae legionis cohortatione ad dextrum cornu profectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 25, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab hac contione legati missi sunt,</quote> <trans><tr>immediately after</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:22:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 22, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:33:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 33, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:47:8" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 47, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:49:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 49, 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab eo magistratu,</quote> <trans><tr>after this office</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 63, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a summā spe novissima exspectabat,</quote> <trans><tr>after the greatest hope</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 50 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Strengthened by the adverbs primum, confestim, statim, protinus, or the adj. recens, <hi rend="ital">immediately after</hi>, <hi rend="ital">soon after</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut primum a tuo digressu Romam veni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 5, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">confestim a proelio expugnatis hostium castris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:36:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 36, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">statim a funere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:85" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 85</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and followed by statim: ab itinere statim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">protinus ab adoptione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:104:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 104, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Homerus qui recens ab illorum actate fuit,</quote> <trans><tr>soon after their time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 5</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:8:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:450 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 450 al.</bibl> (v. also primum, confestim, etc.).— <cit><quote lang="la">Sometimes with the name of a person or place, instead of an action: ibi mihi tuae litterae binae redditae sunt tertio abs te die,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>after their departure from you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: in Italiam perventum est quinto mense a Carthagine Nov[adot  ], i. e. <hi rend="ital">after leaving</hi> (=postquam a Carthagine profecti sunt), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:38:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 38, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">secundo Punico (bello) Scipionis classis XL. die a securi navigavit,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>after its having been built</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 39, 74, § 192</bibl></cit>. —Hence the poct. expression: ab his, <hi rend="ital">after this</hi> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">e\k tou/twn</foreign>), i. e. <hi rend="ital">after these words</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hereupon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 273</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 329</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 612</bibl>; 9, 764.</sense><sense id="n4.13" n="2" level="3"> With reference to a subsequent period. <hi rend="ital">From</hi>, <hi rend="ital">since</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab horā tertiā bibebatur,</quote> <trans><tr>from the third hour</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infinito ex tempore, non ut antea, ab Sullā et Pompeio consulibus,</quote> <trans><tr>since the consulship of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:21:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 21, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vixit ab omni aeternitate,</quote> <trans><tr>from all eternity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:51:115" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 51, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum quo a condiscipulatu vivebat conjunctissime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Lycia semper a terrae motu XL. dies serenos esse,</quote> <trans><tr>after an earthquake</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:211 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 96, 98, § 211 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">centesima lux est haec ab interitu P. Clodii,</quote> <trans><tr>since the death of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:35:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 35, 98</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus a morte quintus hic et tricesimus annus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:6:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 6, 19</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">ab incenso Capitolio illum esse vigesumiun annum,</quote> <trans><tr>since</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 47:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 47, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diebus triginta, a quâ die materia caesa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 36</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes joined with <hi rend="ital">usque</hi> and <hi rend="ital">inde</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod augures omnes usque ab Romulo decreverunt,</quote> <trans><tr>since the time of</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Vat. 8, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam inde ab infelici pugnà ceciderant animi,</quote> <trans><tr>from the very beginning of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 65 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Hence the adverbial expressions ab initio, a principio, a primo, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">from the beginning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at first;</hi> v. initium, principium, primus. Likewise ab integro, <hi rend="ital">anew</hi>, <hi rend="ital">afresh;</hi> v. integer.—Ab ... ad, <hi rend="ital">from</hi> (a time) ... <hi rend="ital">to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab horà octavā ad vesperum secreto collocuti sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 8, 4</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ab horā septimā ad vesperum pugnatum sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:26:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 26, 2</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">a quo tempore ad vos consules anni sunt septingenti octoginta unus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:8:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 8, 4</bibl></cit>; and so in Plautus strengthened by <hi rend="ital">usque</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnata pugnast usque a mane ad vesperum,</quote> <trans><tr>from morning to evening</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 2, 80</bibl>.—Rarely ab ... in: Romani ab sole orto in multum diei stetere in acie, <hi rend="ital">from</hi> ... <hi rend="ital">till late in the day</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 2, 9</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:10:17" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 10, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 31, 31, § 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:229" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 103, 106, § 229</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:89" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 12, 26, § 89</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.14" n="b" level="4"> Particularly with nouns denoting a time of life: <cit><quote lang="la">qui homo cum animo inde ab ineunte aetate depugnat suo,</quote> <trans><tr>from an early age</tr>, <tr>from early youth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 24</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13:44 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 13, 44 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi magna cum co jam inde a pueritiā fuit semper famillaritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 2, 9</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">a pueritiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:11:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 11, 27 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 8, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam inde ab adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam a primā adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab ineunte adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 21, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">followed by ad: usque ad hanc aetatem ab incunte adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a primis temporibus aetatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a teneris unguiculis,</quote> <trans><tr>from childhood</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque a togà purā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 8, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam inde ab incunabulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:36:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 36, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a primā lanugine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">viridi ab aevo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:10" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 10</bibl></cit>, <cb n="AB" /> 17 al.; <cit><quote lang="la">rarely of animals: ab infantiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 63, 83, § 182</bibl></cit>.—Instead of the <hi rend="ital">nom</hi>. <hi rend="ital">abstr</hi>. very often (like the Greek <foreign lang="greek">e\k paio\wn</foreign>, etc.) with concrete substantives: a pucro, ab adulescente, a parvis, etc., <hi rend="ital">from childhood</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui olim a puero parvulo mihi paedagogus fuerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:1:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 1, 90</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">a pausillo puero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a puero,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 36, 115</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 16, 4</bibl> (twice) al.: <cit><quote lang="la">a pueris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:24:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 24, 57</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:1:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 1, 2 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab adulescente,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab infante,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:8:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 8, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a parvā virgine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:66:26 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 66, 26 al.</bibl></cit>—Likewise and in the same sense with adject.: a parvo, <hi rend="ital">from a little child</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">childhood</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:39:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 39, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">a parvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:4:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 4, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a parvulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 23</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab parvulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab tenero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:6:20" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 6, 20</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and rarely of animals: (vacca) a bimā aut trimā fructum ferre incipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.15" n="B" level="2"> In other relations in which the idea of going forth, proceeding, from something is included.</sense><sense id="n4.16" n="1" level="3"> In gen. to denote departure, separation, deterring, avoiding, intermitting, etc., or distance, difference, etc., of inanimate or abstract things. <hi rend="ital">From</hi>: jus atque aecum se a malis spernit procul, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 399, 10</bibl> (Trag. v. 224 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">suspitionem et culpam ut ab se segregent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui discessum animi a corpore putent esse mortem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:9:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 9, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic ab artificio suo non recessit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 10, 20</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">quod si exquiratur usque ab stirpe auctoritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 180</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condicionem quam ab te peto,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 87</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">mercedem gloriae flagitas ab iis, quorum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:15:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 15, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid ab illo acceperis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (i. e. antiquitas) quo propius aberat ab ortu et divinā progenie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:12:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 12, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab defensione desistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 12, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quod tempus ab opere intermitteretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:24:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 7, 24, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut homines adulescentīs a dicendi studio deterream,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 117</bibl></cit>, etc.—Of distance (in order, rank, mind, or feeling): <cit><quote lang="la">qui quartus ab Arcesilā fuit,</quote> <trans><tr>the fourth in succession from</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 12, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu nunc eris alter ab illo,</quote> <trans><tr>next after him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 49</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Aiax, heros ab Achille secundus,</quote> <trans><tr>next in rank to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 193</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid hoc ab illo differt,</quote> <trans><tr>from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:14:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 14, 39</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">hominum vita tantum distat a victu et cultu bestiarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:4:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 4, 15</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">discrepare ab aequitate sapientiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> (v. the verbs differo, disto, discrepo, dissideo, dissentio, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">quae non aliena esse ducerem a dignitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alieno a te animo fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 9, 24</bibl></cit> (v. alienus). —So the expression ab re (qs. <hi rend="ital">aside from the matter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">profit;</hi> cf. the opposite, in rem), <hi rend="ital">contrary to one's profit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to a loss</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disadvantageous</hi> (so in the affirmative very rare and only ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">subdole ab re consulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 88</bibl>; more frequently and class. (but not with Cicero) in the negative, non, haud, ab re, <hi rend="ital">not without advantage</hi> or <hi rend="ital">profit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not useless</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unprofitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adcantageous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haut est ab re aucupis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non ab re esse Quinctii visum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:32:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 32, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:8:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 8, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 3, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:94" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Dogm. Plat. 3, p. 31, 22 al.</bibl> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 3, 44</bibl>, ab re means <hi rend="ital">with respect to the money matter</hi>).</sense><sense id="n4.17" n="2" level="3"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n4.18" n="a" level="4"> To denote an agent from whom an action proceeds, or by whom a thing is done or takes place. <hi rend="ital">By</hi>, and in archaic and solemn style, <hi rend="ital">of</hi>. So most frequently with <hi rend="ital">pass</hi>. or <hi rend="ital">intrans</hi>. <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi> with pass. signif., when the active object is or is considered as a living being: Laudari me abs te, a laudato viro, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:31:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 31, 67</bibl>: injuriā abs te afficior, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 24, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a patre deductus ad Scaevolam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tamquam a praesentibus coram haberi sermo videretur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disputata ab eo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 4</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">illa (i. e. numerorum ac vocum vis) maxime a Graeciā vetere celebrata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:51:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 51, 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita generati a naturā sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:103" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 29, 103</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pars mundi damnata a rerum naturā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26, § 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">niagna adhibita cura est a providentiā deorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:51 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 51 al.</bibl></cit>—With <hi rend="ital">intrans</hi>. <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (i. e. anima) calescit ab eo spiritu,</quote> <trans><tr>is warmed by this breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:55:138" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 55, 138</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 417</bibl>: (mare) quā a <cb n="AB" /> sole collucet, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 105</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">salvebis a meo Cicerone,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>young Cicero sends his compliments to you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a quibus (Atheniensibus) erat profectus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>by whose command</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne vir ab hoste cadat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:36 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 36 al.</bibl></cit>—A substantive or adjective often takes the place of the verb (so with <hi rend="ital">de</hi>, q. v.): <cit><quote lang="la">levior est plaga ab amico quam a debitore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 16, 7</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">a bestiis ictus, morsus, impetus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:6:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 6, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si calor est a sole,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:52" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex iis a te verbis (for a te scriptis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu poenae a Romanis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:23:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 23, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum ingens a Volscis et Aequis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:22:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 22, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad exsolvendam fldem a consule,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 5, 6</bibl></cit>.—With an <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">lassus ab equo indomito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Murus ab ingenic notior ille tuo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:1:126" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 1, 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus a nostris triste malis,</quote> <trans><tr>time made sad by our misfortunes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:3:36" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 3, 36</bibl></cit>.—Different from per: <cit><quote lang="la">vulgo occidebantur: per quos et a quibus?</quote> <trans><tr>by whom and upon whose orders?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:29:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 29, 80</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 34, 97</bibl>: cujus consilio occisus sit, invenio; cujus manu sit percussus, non laboro); so, <cit><quote lang="la">ab hoc destitutus per Thrasybulum (i. e. Thrasybulo auctore),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alc. 5, 4</bibl></cit>.—Ambiguity sometimes arises from the fact that the verb in the pass. would require <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> if used in the active: <cit><quote lang="la">si postulatur a populo,</quote> <trans><tr>if the people demand it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:17:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 17, 58</bibl></cit>, might also mean, <hi rend="ital">if it is required of the people;</hi> on the contrary: quod ab eo (Lucullo) laus imperatoria non admodum exspectabatur, not <hi rend="ital">since he did not expect military renown</hi>, but <hi rend="ital">since they did not expect military renown from him</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 1, 2</bibl>, and so often; cf. Rudd. II. p. 213. (The use of the active dative, or dative of the agent, instead of <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> with the pass., is well known, Zumpt, § 419. It is very seldom found in prose writers of the golden age of Roman liter.; with Cic. sometimes joined with the participles auditus, cognitus, constitutus, perspectus, provisus, susceptus; cf. Halm ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:24:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 24, 71</bibl>, and ad ejusdem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 1, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; but freq. at a later period; e. g. in Pliny, in Books 2-4 of H. N., more than twenty times; and likewise in Tacitus seventeen times. Vid. the passages in Nipperd. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 49</bibl>.) Far more unusual is the <hi rend="ital">simple abl</hi>. in the designation of persons: <cit><quote lang="la">deseror conjuge,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 161</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:75" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:747" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 1, 747</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:274" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 274</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 4, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 6, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and in prose,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:4:2" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 4, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:7:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 7, 8</bibl>; cf. Rudd. II. p. 212; Zumpt ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:V. p. 122" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> V. p. 122</bibl> Spalding.—Hence the adverbial phrase a se=<foreign lang="greek">u)f) e(autou=</foreign>, suā sponte, <hi rend="ital">of one's own uccord</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spontaneously</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsum a se oritur et suā sponte nascitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:24:78" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 24, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(urna) ab se cantat quoja sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 5, 21</bibl></cit> (al. eāpse; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 2, 66</bibl>); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:1:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 1, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:33:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 33, 6</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.19" n="b" level="4"> With names of towns to denote origin, extraction, instead of <hi rend="ital">gentile adjectives</hi>. <hi rend="ital">From</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pastores a Pergamide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Turnus ab Aricia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:50:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 50, 3</bibl></cit> (for which Aricinus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:51:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 51, 1</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">obsides dant trecentos principum a Corā atque Pometiā liberos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:22:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 22, 2</bibl></cit>; and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: O longa mundi servator ab Albā, Auguste, <hi rend="ital">thou who art descended from the old Alban race of kings</hi> (=oriundus, <hi rend="ital">or</hi> ortus regibus Albanis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:6:37" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 6, 37</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.20" n="c" level="4"> In giving the etymology of a name: eam rem (sc. legem, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">no/mon</foreign>) illi Graeco putant nomine a suum cuique tribuendo appellatam, ego nostro a legendo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:6:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 6, 19</bibl>: annum intervallum regni fuit: id ab re ... <hi rend="ital">interregnum</hi> appellatum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 17, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(sinus maris) ab nomine propinquae urbis Ambracius appellatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 4, 3</bibl></cit>; and so Varro in his Ling. Lat., and Pliny, in Books 1-5 of H. N., on almost every page.
