(Cf. also the arts. ex and de.)</sense><sense id="n4.21" n="d" level="4"> With verbs of beginning and repeating: a summo bibere, in Plaut. <hi rend="ital">to drink in succession from the one at the head of the table</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">da, puere, ab summo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 41</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">da ab Delphio cantharum circum, id Most. 1, 4, 33: ab eo nobis causa ordienda est potissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:7:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coepere a fame mala,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:12:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cornicem a caudā de ovo exire,</quote> <trans><tr>tail-foremost</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:16:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 16, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a capite repetis, quod quaerimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:6:18 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 6, 18 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n4.22" n="e" level="4"> With verbs of freeing from, defending, or protecting against any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">a foliis et stercore purgato,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 65</bibl></cit> (66), 1: <cit><quote lang="la">tantumne ab re tuast oti tibi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1</bibl></cit>, <pb n="4" /> <cb n="AB" /> 1, 23; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Saguntini ut a proeliis quietem habuerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 11, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">expiandum forum ab illis nefarii sceleris vestigiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec provincia non modo a calamitate, sed etiam a metu calamitatis est defendenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 6, 14</bibl></cit> (v. defendo): <cit><quote lang="la">ab incendio urbem vigiliis munitam intellegebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut neque sustinere se a lapsu possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:35:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 35, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut meam domum metueret atque a me ipso caveret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:64:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 64, 133</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.23" n="f" level="4"> With verbs of expecting, fearing, hoping, and the like, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>=a parte, as, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 7, 4</bibl>: cum eadem metuam ab hac parte, <hi rend="ital">since I fear the same from this side;</hi> hence, timere, metuere ab aliquo, not, <hi rend="ital">to be afraid of any one, but, to fear something</hi> (proceeding from) <hi rend="ital">from him</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">el metul a Chryside,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 79</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab Hannibale metuens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 36</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">metus a praetore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 15, 7</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Weissenb. ad h. l.: a quo quidem genere, judices, ego numquam timui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:20:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 20, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam nec ab Romanis robis ulla est spes,</quote> <trans><tr>you can expect nothing from the Romans</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 13, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.24" n="g" level="4"> With verbs of fastening and holding: <cit><quote lang="la">funiculus a puppi religatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51:154" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 51, 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sinistra capillum ejus a vertice teneret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0478,001:Pet. Cons. 3" default="NO"><author>Q. Cic.</author> Pet. Cons. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.25" n="h" level="4"> Ulcisci se ab aliquo, <hi rend="ital">to take vengeance on one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a ferro sanguis humanus se ulciscitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:14:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 14, 41 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n4.26" n="i" level="4"> Cognoscere ab aliquâ re <hi rend="ital">to knoio</hi> or <hi rend="ital">learn by means of something</hi> (different from <hi rend="ital">ab aliquo</hi>, to learn from some one): <cit><quote lang="la">id se a Gallicis armis atque insignibus cognovisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 22</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.27" n="j" level="4"> Dolere, laborare, valere ab, instead of the simple <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">doleo ab animo, doleo ab oculis, doleo ab aegritudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a morbo valui, ab animo aeger fui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 26</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a frigore et aestu ne quid laborent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:2:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 2, 17</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">a frigore laborantibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 10, 46, § 133</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">laborare ab re frumentaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 9</bibl>; v. laboro.</sense><sense id="n4.28" n="k" level="4"> Where verbs and adjectives are joined with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, instead of the simple <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> defines more exactly the respect in which that which is expressed by the verb or adj. is to be understood, <hi rend="ital">in relation to, with regard to, in respect to, on the part of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab ingenio improbus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a me pudica'st,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 1, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">orba ab optimatibus contio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 23, 54</bibl></cit>; ro <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6,156</bibl>: securos vos ab hac parte reddemus, Planc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> (v. securus): <cit><quote lang="la">locus copiosus a frumento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 18, 2</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">sumus imparati cum a militibas tum a pecunià,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 15</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille Graecus ab omni laude felicior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:16:63" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 16, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab unà parte haud satis prosperuin,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:32:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 32, 2 al.</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so often in poets ab arte=arte,</quote> <trans><tr>artfully</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:4" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 5, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:9:66" default="NO">1, 9, 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 4, 30</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.29" n="l" level="4"> In the statement of the motive instead of ex, propter, or the simple <case>abl.</case> causae, <hi rend="ital">from, out of, on account of, in consequence of</hi>: ab singulari amore scribo, Balb. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 7</bibl>, B <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">linguam ab irrisu exserentem,</quote> <trans><tr>thrusting out the tongue in derision</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:10:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 10, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab honore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>; so, ab irā, a spe, ab odio, v. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:30:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 30, 1</bibl>: 26, 1, 3; cf. also Kritz and Fabri ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31, 3</bibl>, and Fabri ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:36:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 36, 7</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.30" n="m" level="4"> Especially in the poets instead of the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab illo injuria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fulgor ab auro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dulces a fontibus undae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 243</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n4.31" n="n" level="4"> In indicating a part of the whole, for the more usual ex, <hi rend="ital">of, out of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scuto ab novissimis uni militi detracto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 25, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nonnuill ab novissimis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:65:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 65, 137</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 59</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: a quibus (captivis) ad Senatum missus (Regulus).</sense><sense id="n4.32" n="o" level="4"> In marking that from which any thing proceeds, and <hi rend="ital">to which it belongs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui sunt ab eā disciplinā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:3:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab eo qui sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:3:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nostri illi a Platone et Aristotele aiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:30:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 30, 63</bibl></cit> (in imitation of <foreign lang="greek">oi/ u)po/ tinos</foreign>).</sense><sense id="n4.33" n="p" level="4"> To designate an <hi rend="ital">office</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dignity</hi> (with or without servus; so not freq. till after the Aug. period; <cit><quote lang="la">in Cic. only once): Pollex, servus a pedibus meus,</quote> <trans><tr>one of my couriers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 5, 1</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">a manu servus,</quote> <trans><tr>a secretary</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:74" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 74</bibl></cit>: Narcissum ab eplstulis (<hi rend="ital">secretary</hi>) et Pallantem a rationibus (<hi rend="ital">accountant</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 28</bibl>; and so, ab actis, ab <cb n="ABAC" /> admissione, ab aegris, ab apothecā, ab argento, a balneis, a bibliothecà, a codicillis, a jumentis, a potione, etc. (v. these words and Inscr. Orell. vol. 3, Ind. xi. p. 181 sq.).</sense><sense id="n4.34" n="q" level="4"> The use of <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> before adverbs is for the most part peculiar to later Latinity: <cit><quote lang="la">a peregre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 7</bibl></cit> (6), 8: <cit><quote lang="la">a foris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:24:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen, 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:23:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 23, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab intus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 7, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab invicem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:25:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 25, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cypr.</author> Ep. 63, 9</bibl>: <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a longe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 257" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 257</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:22:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 22, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:26:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 26, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a modo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 23, 39</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Hier. Vit. Hilar.: a nune,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 1, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a sursum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:15:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 15, 38</bibl></cit>.← </sense><sense id="n4.35" n="a" level="4"><hi rend="ital">Ab</hi> is not repeated like most other prepositions (v. ad, ex, in, etc.) with <hi rend="ital">pron. interrog</hi>. or <hi rend="ital">relat</hi>. after <hi rend="ital">subst</hi>. and <hi rend="ital">pron. demonstr. with ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arsinoën, Stratum, Naupactum...fateris ab hostibus esse captas. Quibus autem hostibus? Nempe iis, quos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:37:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 37, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a rebus gerendis senectus abstrahit. Quibus? An iis, quae in juventute geruntur et viribus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Jove incipiendum putat. Quo Jove?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:36:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 36, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res publica, quascumque vires habebit, ab iis ipsis, quibus tenetur, de te propediem impetrabit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:13:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 13, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4.36" n="b" level="4"> Ab in Plantus is once put after the word which it governs: quo ab, As. 1, 1, 106.—</sense><sense id="n4.37" n="c" level="4"> It is in various ways separated from the word which it governs: <cit><quote lang="la">a vitae periculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:91:313" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 91, 313</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a nullius umquam me tempore aut commodo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a minus bono,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a satis miti principio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">damnis dives ab ipsā suis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 96</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:12:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 18</bibl>; 13, 116.—</sense><sense id="n4.38" n="d" level="4"> The poets join <hi rend="ital">a</hi> and <hi rend="ital">que</hi>, making <hi rend="ital">aque;</hi> but in good prose <hi rend="ital">que</hi> is annexed to the following <case>abl.</case> (a meque, abs teque, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">aque Chao,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:347" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 347</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aque mero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:631" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 631</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aque viro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 6, 156</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aque suis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:2:74 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 2, 74 al.</bibl></cit> But: <cit><quote lang="la">a meque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:16:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 16, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abs teque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 3, 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a teque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 11</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">7: a primāque adulescentiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:91:315 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 91, 315 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n4.39" n="e" level="4"> A Greek noun joined with ab stands in the <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: a parte negotiati, hoc est <foreign lang="greek">pragmatikh=</foreign>, removisse, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:7:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 7, 1</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n4.40" n="III" level="1"> In composition <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, </sense><sense id="n4.41" n="1" level="3"> Retains its original signif.: abducere, <hi rend="ital">to take</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carry away</hi> from some place: abstrahere, <hi rend="ital">to draw auay;</hi> also, <hi rend="ital">downward</hi>: abicere, <hi rend="ital">to throw down;</hi> and denoting a departure from the idea of the simple word, it has an effect apparently <hi rend="ital">privative</hi>: absimilis, departing from the similar, <hi rend="ital">unlike</hi>: abnormis, departing from the rule, <hi rend="ital">unusual</hi> (different from <hi rend="ital">dissimilis, enormis</hi>); and so also in amens=a mente remotus, alienus (<hi rend="ital">out of one's senses, without self-control, insane</hi>): absurdus, <hi rend="ital">missounding</hi>, then <hi rend="ital">incongruous, irrational</hi>: abutor (in one of its senses), <hi rend="ital">to misuse</hi>: aborior, abortus, <hi rend="ital">to miscarry</hi>: abludo; for the privative force the Latin regularly employs <hi rend="ital">in-</hi>, v. 2. in.— </sense><sense id="n4.42" n="2" level="3"> It more rarely designates completeness, as in absorbere, abutor (<hi rend="ital">to use up</hi>). (The designation of the fourth generation in the ascending or descending line by <hi rend="ital">ab</hi> belongs here only in appearance; as <hi rend="ital">abavus</hi> for quartus pater, <hi rend="ital">great-great-grandfather</hi>, although the Greeks introduced <foreign lang="greek">u\po/pappos</foreign>; for the immutability of the syllable ab in abpatrnus and abmatertera, as well as the signif. of the word abavus, grandfather's grandfather, imitated in abnepos, grandchild's grandchild, seems to point to a derivation from avi avus, as Festus, p. 13 Mūll., explains <hi rend="ital">atavus</hi>, by atta avi, or, rather, attae avus.)</sense></entryFree>
aba: <entryFree id="n5" type="main" key="Aba"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aba</orth>. (or Abas), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, v. Aga.</entryFree>
ababus: <entryFree id="n6" type="spur" key="Ababus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ababus</orth>, false read. in inscrr., written for abavus.</entryFree>
abactor: <entryFree id="n7" type="main" key="a^bactor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbactor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>abigo</etym>,=abigeus and abigeator, <sense id="n7.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who drives off, a driver off</hi> (late Latin): pecorum, Firm. Astr. 6, 31; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 10, 14</bibl>; and boum, Min. Fel. O-ct. 5; and <hi rend="ital">absol., a cuttle-stealer</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thief</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 7, p. 199 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl> Elm.; Paul. Sent. ō, 18, 1.</sense></entryFree>
abactus: <entryFree id="n8" type="main" key="a^bactus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of abigo, q. v.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n9" type="hapax" key="a^bactus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbactus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>abigo</etym>, <sense id="n9.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a driving away, robbing</hi> (of cattle, vessels, etc.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:20:4" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 20, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abaculus: <entryFree id="n10" type="hapax" key="a^ba^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbăcŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>abacus</etym>, <sense id="n10.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small cube or tile of colored glass for making ornamental pavements</hi>, the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">u\buki/skos</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 26, 67, § 199</bibl>. <cb n="ABAL" /></sense></entryFree>
abacus: <entryFree id="n11" type="greek" key="a^ba^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbăcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype> (according to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 752</bibl> P. also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbax</orth>, ăcis; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> p. 688</bibl>), <gen>m.</gen>,=<foreign lang="greek">a)/bac, a^kos</foreign>, prop. <sense id="n11.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a square tublet;</hi> hence, in partic., </sense><sense id="n11.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A sideboard, the top of which was made of marble, sometimes of silver, gold, or other precious material, chiefly used for the display of gold and silver vessels</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:16:section=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 16, § 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 4, 25, § 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:21:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 21, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=46" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 46</bibl> Mūll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 2, 6, § 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:2" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 2</bibl>-0-4: <cit><quote lang="la">perh. also called mensae Delphicae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 59 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit> Zumpt; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:67" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 67</bibl>. Accord. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 6, 7</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 3, 8, § 14</bibl>, Cn. Manlius Vulso flrst brought them from Asia to Rome, B.C. 187, in his triumph over the Galatae; cf. Becker, Gall. 2, p. 258 (2d edit.).—</sense><sense id="n11.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A gaming-board, divided into compurtments</hi>, for playing with dice or counters, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:22" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 5</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n11.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A counting-table,</hi> covered with sand or dust, and used for arithmetical computation, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:131" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 131</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 284</bibl>; cf. Becker, Gall. 2, p. 65. —</sense><sense id="n11.4" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A wooden tray</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 10, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11.5" n="V" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A painted panel or square compariment in the wall or ceiling of a chamber</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 3, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 12, 56, § 159</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:3" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 1, 1, § 3</bibl>, and 35, 6, 13, § 32.—</sense><sense id="n11.6" n="VI" level="1"> In architecture, <hi rend="ital">a fiat, square stone on the top of a column</hi>, immediately under the architrare, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:5:5 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 5, 5 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 1, 11</bibl> sq.</sense></entryFree>
abaddir: <entryFree id="n12" type="main" key="A_baddir"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ābaddir</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ābădir</orth>), <itype>indecl.</itype> or <itype>īris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Heb. <foreign />, mighty father</etym>, <sense id="n12.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of an Oriental deity</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 647</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
abaddon: <entryFree id="n13" type="main" key="Abaddon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abaddon</orth>,<gen>m.</gen> <itype>indecl.</itype> <etym>Heb. destruction</etym>, <sense id="n13.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of the angel of Tartarus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Apoc. 9, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abaestuo: <entryFree id="n14" type="hapax" key="a^baestu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-aestŭo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> (prop. to wave down, hence), <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <sense id="n14.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to hang down richly</hi>: laetis ut vitis abaestuet uvis, Poët. (Tert. or Cypr.) de Jud. D-om. l.</sense></entryFree>
abagio: <entryFree id="n15" type="spur" key="abagio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abagio</orth>, <itype>ōnis, the supposed etymology of adagio</itype>, by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=31" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 31</bibl> Mūll.</entryFree>
abagmentum: <entryFree id="n16" type="hapax" key="a^bagmentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbagmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>abigo</etym>, <sense id="n16.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a means for procuring abortion</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Med. 2, 34</bibl> dub.</sense></entryFree>
abalienatio: <entryFree id="n17" type="hapax" key="a^ba^li^e_na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbălĭēnātĭo</orth>, ōnis, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abalieno</etym>, <sense id="n17.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a legal transfer of property by</hi> sale or other alienation: <cit><quote lang="la">abalienatio est ejus rei, quae mancipi est, aut traditio alteri nexu aut in jure cessio, inter quos ea jure civili fieri possunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
abalieno: <entryFree id="n18" type="main" key="a^ba^li^e_no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-ălĭēno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, orig. <sense id="n18.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make alien from</hi> one or <hi rend="ital">from</hi> one's self, i.e. <hi rend="ital">to remove, separate</hi>. </sense><sense id="n18.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop. </sense><sense id="n18.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">istuc crucior a viro me tali abalienarier,</quote> <trans><tr>to be separated from such a man</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:8:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 8, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 112</bibl> and 156 (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 26</bibl>, the correct read. is <hi rend="ital">alienavit</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n18.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n18.4" n="1" level="3"> T. t., <hi rend="ital">to convey the ownership of a thing to another, to make a legal transfer, to sell, alienate</hi> (cf. abalienatio): <cit><quote lang="la">eam (picturam) vendat: ni in quadriduo Abalienârit, quo ex argentum acceperit,</quote> <trans><tr>has sold</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:4:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 4, 1, 20</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">agros vectigales populi Romani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:24:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 24, 64</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 27, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:3:14" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 10, 3, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:50:section=119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 50, § 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sepulcrum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4357</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid ab se,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3673</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n18.5" n="2" level="3"> In med. lang.: <cit><quote lang="la">membra morbis atalienata,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>dead</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:75" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opium sensus abalienat,</quote> <trans><tr>makes unconscious</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 190" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 190</bibl></cit>: cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:ib. 192" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 192</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n18.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n18.7" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to separate, remove, abstract</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi mors meum animum aps to abalienavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 18</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">assueti malis abalienaverant ab sensu rerum suarum animos,</quote> <trans><tr>had abstracted their thoughts from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 42 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de minuti capite, abalienati jure civium,</quote> <trans><tr>deprived of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:60:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 60, 15</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n18.8" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">to alienate, estrange, render disaffected</hi> (Ciceron.: syn.: alienare, inimicissimum reddere, disjungere; opp. conciliare, retinere); constr. <hi rend="ital">aliquem</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aliquid</hi>. with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, the <case>abl.</case> or <case>acc.</case> only, or quite <hi rend="ital">absol</hi>. (<hi rend="ital">a</hi>) With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si in homines caros acerbius invehare, nonne a te judices abalienes?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:75:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 75, 304</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 48</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 3, 25, 98; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 8, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vaide benevolentiam concillant abalienantque ab iis, in quibus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:43:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 43, 182</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum ab se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 6, 1</bibl></cit>. — </sense><sense id="n18.9" n="(b)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo erant ipsl propter judicia abalienati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:48:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 48, 199</bibl></cit> B. and K.: quod Tissaphernes perjurio <pb n="5" /> <cb n="ABBA" /> suo et homines suis rebus abalienaret et deos sibi iratos redderet, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 2, 5</bibl> (cf. supra, II. A., the passage of <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:60:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 60, 15</bibl>). —</sense><sense id="n18.10" n="(g)" level="5"> The <hi rend="ital">acc</hi>. only: <cit><quote lang="la">qui nos, quos favendo In communi causā retinere potuerunt, invidendo abalienārunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 7, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam Africam,</quote> <trans><tr>to estrange</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,022:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ham. 2, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:ib. 2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(noster amicus) mirandum in modum est animo abalienato,</quote> <trans><tr>alien ated</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">indigna patientium abalienabantur animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:38:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 38, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n18.11" n="(d)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> (very rate): <cit><quote lang="la">timebant ne arguendo abalienarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:S, 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> S, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> (for which, in the foll. ch.: ita Campanos abalienavit).</sense></entryFree>
abambulantes: <entryFree id="n19" type="gloss" key="a^bambu^lantes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbambŭlantes</orth>: abscedentes, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26:10" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26, 10</bibl> Mūll.</entryFree>
abamita: <entryFree id="n20" type="main" key="a^ba^mi^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbămĭta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>avus-amita</etym>, <sense id="n20.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sister of an</hi> abavus, or great - great - grandfather; <cit><quote lang="la">also called amita maxima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:section=17" default="NO">10, § 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abante: <entryFree id="n21" type="gloss" key="a^bante"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbante</orth> <etym>ab-ante, like Incircum, insuper, etc.; cf. also the Heb. <foreign /> and the Engl. from before</etym>. <sense id="n21.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Prep</hi>. with <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">from before</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abante oculis parcntis rapuerunt nymphae,</quote> <trans><tr>away before the eyes of the father</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 717, 11</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n21.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adv</hi>., <hi rend="ital">before</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne (quis) abante aliam (arcam) ponat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4396</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abantius: <entryFree id="n22" type="main" key="A^banti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbantĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n22.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of Abantia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">another name of Euboœa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">classis,</quote> <trans><tr>Eubosan</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:8:46" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 8, 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abarcet: <entryFree id="n23" type="main" key="abarcet"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abarcet</orth>: prohibet, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=15" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 15</bibl> Mūll.; cf. abercet.</entryFree>
abaris: <entryFree id="n24" type="main" key="A^ba^ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbăris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n24.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Rutulian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Euryalus; acc</hi>. Abarim, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:344" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 344</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n24.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A companion of Phineus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Perseus; acc</hi>. Abarin, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abaritanus: <entryFree id="n25" type="main" key="A^ba^ri^ta_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbărĭtānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n25.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of Abaris, a place in Africa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">harundo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:172" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 36, 66, § 172</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abas: <entryFree id="n26" type="main" key="A^bas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbas</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>=”<foreign lang="greek">*abas</foreign>. <sense id="n26.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The twelfth king of Argos, son of Lynceus and Hypermnestra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandson of Danaūs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Acrisius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and grandfather of Perseus</hi>. His shield was gained by Æneas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:286" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 286</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.1" n="B" level="2"> Hence derivv. </sense><sense id="n26.2" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăb-antĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Abas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 164</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.3" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbantĭădēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">patron</hi>., <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Abas</hi>. </sense><sense id="n26.4" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">His son Acrisius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:607" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 607</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.5" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">His great grandson Perseus</hi> (by Danaë, daughter of Acrisius), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:673" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 673</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 138 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n26.6" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Centaur</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Ixion</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:306" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 306</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n26.7" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An Ethiopian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 126</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.8" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A companion of Dionedes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:505" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 505</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.9" n="V" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A companion of Æneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 121</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n26.10" n="VI" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Tuscan chieftain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:170" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 170</bibl> and 427.</sense></entryFree>
abascantus: <entryFree id="n27" type="greek" key="a^bascantus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbascantus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">u)bu(skantos</foreign>, <sense id="n27.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">unenvied</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeon,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Gnost. 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abathon: <entryFree id="n28" type="spur" key="abathon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abathon</orth>, false read. in Vitr. for <foreign lang="greek">a)/buton</foreign>.</entryFree>
abatos: <entryFree id="n29" type="main" key="Aba^to^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abătŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, =”<foreign lang="greek">*abatos</foreign> (inaccess (ble), <sense id="n29.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rocky island. in the Nile</hi>, not far from Philæ, to which the priests only had access, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:323" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 323</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4:2:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 4, 2, 7</bibl>, written as Greek, <foreign lang="greek">*)/abatos</foreign>).</sense></entryFree>
abavia: <entryFree id="n30" type="main" key="a^ba^vi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-ăvĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>avus, avia</etym>, <sense id="n30.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">mother of a great-grandfather</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">of a great-grandmother</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1, § 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:section=17" default="NO">10, § 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abavunculus: <entryFree id="n31" type="main" key="a^ba^vuncu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-ăvuncŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">great-greatuncle;</hi> also called avunculus maximus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:section=17" default="NO">10, § 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abavus: <entryFree id="n32" type="main" key="a^ba^vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-ăvus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n32.0" n="1" level="3"> (=avi avus, cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Mūll.) <hi rend="ital">Great-greatgrandfather</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 4, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:58:213" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 58, 213</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:11:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 11, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11, 38</bibl> (B. and K.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1</bibl>, § G; 10, § 15; called by Vergil <hi rend="ital">quartus pater</hi>, A. 10, 619.—</sense><sense id="n32.1" n="2" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">forefather, ancestor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 6, 8, § 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Clem. 1:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Clem. 1,10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abax: <entryFree id="n33" type="main" key="abax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abax</orth>, <itype>acis</itype>, v. abacus <sense id="n33.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
abba: <entryFree id="n34" type="main" key="Abba1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, false read. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 7, 10</bibl>, Instead of <sense id="n34.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Obba</hi>, q. v.)</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n35" type="main" key="abba2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abba</orth>, <itype>indecl.</itype>,=ů<foreign lang="greek">bb</foreign>ū [Chald. Abba, Heb. ab], <sense id="n35.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">father</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 14, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 8, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,009:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gal. 4, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abbas: <entryFree id="n36" type="main" key="abba_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abbās</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n36.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the head of an ecclesiastical community, an abbot</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> 16, 114</bibl>; Inscr. Mommsen, 3485 (A. D. 468).—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">abbātissa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an abbess</hi>, Inscr. Mommsen, 3896 (A. D. 570); and <orth extent="full" lang="la">abbātĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an abbey</hi> (eccl. Lat.), Hler. <cb n="ABDI" /></sense></entryFree>
abbassus: <entryFree id="n37" type="main" key="Abbassus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abbassus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, =<foreign lang="greek">*)/ambason</foreign>, <sense id="n37.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Abbassus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a town in Phrygia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
abbreviatio: <entryFree id="n38" type="main" key="abbre^via^tio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abbrĕviătio</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abbrevio</etym>, <sense id="n38.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an abbreviation, a diminution</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:10:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 10, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abbrevio: <entryFree id="n39" type="main" key="abbre^vi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-brĕvĭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. freq. a.</pos> <etym>ab <hi rend="ital">or</hi> adbrevio</etym>, <sense id="n39.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to shorten, abridge</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 3</bibl> prol.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:10:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 10, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:9:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 9, 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abcido: <entryFree id="n40" type="spur" key="abci_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-cīdo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, cīdi</itype>, an incorrect form for <sense id="n40.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abscído</hi>, q. v.</sense></entryFree>
abdalonymus: <entryFree id="n41" type="main" key="Abdalony^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abdalonymus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Abdol-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, a <sense id="n41.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Sidonian of royal descent, made king of Sidon by Alexander the Great</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:1:19 sq" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 1, 19 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:10:8" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 10, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abdera: <entryFree id="n42" type="main" key="Abde_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abdēra</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, and <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, =<foreign lang="greek">*)/abo)hra</foreign>. <sense id="n42.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Abdera, a town on the southern coast of Thrace, not far from the mouth of the Nestus, noted for the stupidity of its inhabitants. It was the birthplace of the philosophers Protagoras, Democritus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and Anaxarchus; n.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:29:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 29, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:3:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 3, 3</bibl>; <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:469" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 469</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 8, 53, § 94</bibl> dub.; <cit><quote lang="la">4, 11, 18, § 42: hic Abdera, non tacente me,</quote> <trans><tr>here was Abdera itself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:17:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 17, 3</bibl></cit> (4, 16, 6).—</sense><sense id="n42.1" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Folly, stupidity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">madness</hi>, Cic. l. l. (cf.: id est <foreign lang="greek">*)abo)hritiko/n</foreign>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">stupid</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 7, 4</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, p. 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:50" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:25:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 25, 4</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n42.2" n="B" level="2"> Hence, derivv. </sense><sense id="n42.3" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Abdērīta</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Abdērītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, =<foreign lang="greek">*)abo)hrits</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">an Abderite</hi>: Democritus Abderites, Laber. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:17" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abderites Protagoras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:23:63" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 23, 63</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de Protagora Abderita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:32:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 32, 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abderitae legati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 4, 8</bibl></cit>; cf. id. § 12 sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15:2 al" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 15, 2 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n42.4" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ab-dērītānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of Abdera</hi>, meton. for <hi rend="ital">stupid, foolish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abderitanae pectora plebis habes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:25:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 25, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n42.5" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city of</hi> Hispania Baetlca, <hi rend="ital">on the southern coast</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Adra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:6:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 6, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 3, § 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abdicatio: <entryFree id="n43" type="main" key="abdi^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭcātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abdĭco</etym>, <sense id="n43.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a renouncing, disowning</hi>. </sense><sense id="n43.1" n="1" level="3"> Jurid. t. t.: <cit><quote lang="la">hereditatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 6, 31, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberorum,</quote> <trans><tr>disinheriting</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 6, 8, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:4:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 4, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:77" default="NO">3, 6, 77</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:15" default="NO">7, 1, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:150 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 45, 46, § 150 al.</bibl>; cf. Dirksen, Versuch., etc., Leipz. 1823, p. 62 sq.—*</sense><sense id="n43.2" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="dom">Polit. t. t.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a renunciation of an office, abdication</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dictaturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
abdicative: <entryFree id="n44" type="main" key="abdi^ca_ti_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭcātīvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. abdicativus.</entryFree>
abdicativus: <entryFree id="n45" type="main" key="abdi^ca^ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭcătīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>abdĭco</etym>. In later philos. lang.=negativus, <sense id="n45.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">negative</hi> (opp. to dedicativus, <hi rend="ital">affirmative</hi>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Pseudo</author> ysp. Dogm. Plat. p. 30</bibl> Elm. (266 Ord.); <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, p. 121</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭcātīvē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">negatively</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">concludere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, p. 128</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abdicatrix: <entryFree id="n46" type="main" key="abdi^ca_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭcātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n46.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that renounces</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disclaims</hi> any thing (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">misericordiae (humanitas),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Salv.</author> adv. Avar. 11, p. 76</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abdico: <entryFree id="n47" type="main" key="abdi^co1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-dĭco</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (prop. <sense id="n47.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to indicate, announce</hi> something as <hi rend="ital">not belonging</hi> to one; hence), </sense><sense id="n47.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to deny, disown, refuse, reject</hi>.—With <case>acc.</case> und <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: mortem ostentant, regno expellunt, consanguineam esse abdicant, <hi rend="ital">deny her to be</hi>, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 450, 30</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 84 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">abdicat enim voluptati inesse bonitatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pseudo</author> Apul. de Dogm. Plat. 3 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>—With <case>acc.</case> (so very freq. in the elder Pliny): naturam abdico, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 306, 32</bibl> (Trag. p. 120 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">ubi plus mali quam boni reperio, id totum abdico atque eicio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:24:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 24, 102</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legem agrariam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 30, 31, § 116</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corticem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 13, 22, 43, § 124</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea (signa) in totum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 4, 5, § 16</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">utinam posset e vita in totum abdicari (aurum),</quote> <trans><tr>be got rid of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 1, 3, § 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni venere abdicata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:73 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 17, 15, § 73 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n47.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n47.3" n="A" level="2"> Jurid. t. t., <hi rend="ital">to renounce</hi> one, partic. a son, <hi rend="ital">to disinherit</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">qui ex duobus legitlmis alterum in adoptionem dederat, alterum abdicaverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:97" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 97</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">minus dicto audientem fllium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex meretrice natum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:82 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 1, 82 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae in scholis abdicatorum, haee in foro exheredatorum a parcntibus ratio cst,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:4:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 4, 11</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">pater abdicans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:59" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 59</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">filius abdicantis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:95" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 2, 95</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">abdicandi jus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:77" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 6, 77</bibl></cit>.—Hence, patrem, <hi rend="ital">to disoun</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:10:3" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 10, 3</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n47.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="dom">Polit. t. t.</usg>: abdicare se magistratu, or <hi rend="ital">absol</hi>. (prop. to detach one's self from an office, hence), <hi rend="ital">to renounce</hi> an office, <hi rend="ital">to resign, abdicate</hi> (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">deponere magistratum): consules magistratu se abdicaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:35:74" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 35, 74</bibl></cit>; so, so magistrutu, id. <cb n="ABDO" /> Leg. 2, 12, 31; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:15:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 15, 4 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se dictatu. rā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:31:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 31, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:26:18 al" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 26, 18 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sc consulatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:22:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 22, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se praeturā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se aedilitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:39:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 39, 9</bibl></cit> etc. Likewise: <cit><quote lang="la">se tutelā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1, 4</bibl></cit>; and fig.: se scriptu, Piso ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:9:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 9, 4</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">eo die (Antonius) se non modo consulatu, sed etiam libertate abdicavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 5, 12</bibl></cit>. — <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: augures rem ad senatum; <cit><quote lang="la">senatus, ut abdicarent consules: abdicaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:4:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 4, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n47.5" n="b" level="4"> With <case>acc.</case> a few times in the historians: <cit><quote lang="la">(patres) abdicare consulatum jubentes et deponere imperium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 28 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abdicando dictaturam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:18:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 18, 4</bibl></cit>.—In <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abdicato magistratu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 47:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 47, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">inter priorem dictaturam abdicatam novamque a Manlio initam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa non abdicandae dictaturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 49 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n48" type="main" key="abdi_co2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-dīco</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> A word peculiar to augural and judicial lang. (opp. addīco). *<sense id="n48.0" n="I" level="1"> Of an unfavorable omen, <hi rend="ital">nod to assent to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tres partes (vineae) aves abdixissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:17:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 17, 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n48.1" n="II" level="1"> In judicial lang.: abdicere vindicias ab aliquo, <hi rend="ital">to take away by sentence</hi> (=abjudicare), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:2:24" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 2, 24</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:56:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 56, 4</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
abdite: <entryFree id="n49" type="main" key="abdi^te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭtē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. abdo, <sense id="n49.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
abditivus: <entryFree id="n50" type="main" key="abdi^ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭtīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>abdo</etym>. <sense id="n50.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Removed or separated from</hi> = remotus, sejunctus: <cit><quote lang="la">a patre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 65</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n50.1" n="II" level="1"> ABDITIVI: abortivi, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=22" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 22</bibl> Müll. (without an example).</sense></entryFree>
abditus: <entryFree id="n51" type="main" key="abdi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of abdo.</entryFree>
abdo: <entryFree id="n52" type="main" key="abdo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-do</orth>, <itype>ĭdi, ĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>2. do</etym>. <sense id="n52.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to put away, remove</hi>: and abdere se, <hi rend="ital">to go away, betake one's self</hi> to some place: <cit><quote lang="la">ex conspectu eri sui se abdiderunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestres copias paulum ab eo loco abditas in locis superioribus constituunt,</quote> <trans><tr>removed, withdrawn</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:79:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 79, 2</bibl></cit>; so with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ascensu abdito a conspectu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 14, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">procul ardentes hinc precor abde faces,</quote> <trans><tr>remove</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:1:82" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 1, 82</bibl></cit>.—The <hi rend="ital">terminus ad quem</hi> is usually expressed by <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abdidit se in intimam Macedoniam quo potuit longissime a castris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:29:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 29, 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">se in contrariam partem terrarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:41:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 41, 89</bibl></cit>: se in classem, Dolab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 9, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se in Menapios,</quote> <trans><tr>to depart</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">In silvam Arduennam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitum in interiora,</quote> <trans><tr>to uithdraw</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:110:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 110, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea in insulam Seriphon abdita est (=ex humanā societate quasi expulsa),</quote> <trans><tr>banished, exiled</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se in bibliothecam,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to retire to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 28</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">se totum in litteras,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 33, 2</bibl></cit>.—Rarely with other <hi rend="ital">prepositions</hi> or with <hi rend="ital">local adv.</hi>: Audisne haec, Amphiaraë, sub terram abdite? Poët. (Att.?) ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:25:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 25, 60</bibl>; so with <hi rend="ital">sub</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:419" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 419</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se rus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:38:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 38, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se Arpinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 6, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n52.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to hide, conceal, keep secret</hi>, etc. (syn.: occulto, recondo); constr. <hi rend="ital">aliquid</hi>, without or with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>, with other <hi rend="ital">prepositions</hi>, with <case>abl.</case> only, or <hi rend="ital">dat</hi>., with a <hi rend="ital">localadv</hi>. </sense><sense id="n52.2" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Aliquid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae partes corporis ... aspectum essent deformem habiturae, eas contexit atque abdidit (natura),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35:126" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35, 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amici tabellas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:17:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 17, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimas, operire luctum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 16, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abduntur (delphini) occultanturque incognito more,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:H. N. 9:8:7:section=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> H. N. 9, 8, 7, § 22</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">occultare et abdere pavorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnare cupiebant, sed retro revocanda et abdenda cupiditas erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:45:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 45, 7</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">sensus suos penitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid dissimulata offensione,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 64</bibl></cit>. — </sense><sense id="n52.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum se ille fugiens in scalarum tenebris abdidisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:15:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 15, 40</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui dispersos homines in agris et in tectis silvestribus abditos ... compulit unum in locum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inr. 1, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abditi in tabernaculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:39:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 39, 4</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in silvis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 19, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">penitus qui in ferrost abditus aër,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1037 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1037 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n52.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With other <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cultrum, quem sub veste abditum habebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 58 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:715" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 715</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferrum carvo tenus hamo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:719" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 719</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">o)</foreign>) With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput cristatā casside,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus corneā domo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 6, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gladium sinu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 5, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">latet abditus agro,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc (equum) abde domo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita se litteris abdiderunt, at, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 6, 12</bibl></cit>; v. Halm ad h. l.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">dat</hi>. (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">lateri capulo tenus abdidit ensem,</quote> <trans><tr>he baried</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:553" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 553</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">local adv.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus humi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:12:38" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 12, 38</bibl></cit>.—Hence. <pb n="6" /> <cb n="ABDU" /> <orth extent="full" lang="la">abditus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., hidden, concealed, secreted, secret</hi> (syn.: reconditus, abscontlitus, occultus, retrusus): sub terram abditi, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:25:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 25, 60</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vis abdita quaedum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1233" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1233</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res occultae et penitus abditae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt innumerabiles de his rebus libri neque abditi neque obscuri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:20:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 20, 84</bibl></cit>: haec esse penitus in mediā philosophiā; <cit><quote lang="la">retrusa atque abdita,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 19, 87</bibl></cit> al.: oppida, <hi rend="ital">remote</hi>, Cod. Th. 15, 1, 14. —<hi rend="ital">Comp</hi>. abditior, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 5:5" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 5, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:10:10" default="NO">10, 10</bibl>. —Sup. abditissimus, Aug. Enchir. c. 16. —</sense><sense id="n52.5" n="II" level="1">In the <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭtum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrai abdita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:809" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 809</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">abdita rerum (=abditae res),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> A.P. 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in abdito coire,</quote> <trans><tr>in concealment, secretly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 5, 5, § 13</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">abdĭtē</orth> <hi rend="ital">secretly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">latuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:73:section=181" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 73, § 181</bibl></cit>; Ambros. Job et Dav. 1, 9, 29.</sense></entryFree>
abdolonymus: <entryFree id="n53" type="main" key="Abdo^lo^ny^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Abdŏlŏnymus</orth>, <sense id="n53.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v.</hi> Abdalonymus.</sense></entryFree>
abdomen: <entryFree id="n54" type="main" key="abdo^me^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abdŏmĕn</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>etym. uncertain; perh. for adipomen, from adeps, or perh. from abdo, to conceal, cover</etym>, <sense id="n54.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the fat lower part of the belly, the paunch, abdomen</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">lapa/ra</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n54.1" n="I" level="1"><usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of men and animals: abdomina thynni, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 35, 22</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:51:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 51, 77 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:37:84" default="NO" valid="yes">11, 37, 84</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:107" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 107</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 10, 104</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n54.2" n="II" level="1"><usg type="style">Meton.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">gluttony, sensuality</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille heluo natus abdomini suo, non laudi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:17:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 17, 41</bibl></cit>; so, natus abdomini, Treb. Gall. 17; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:27:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 27, 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:51:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 51, 110</bibl>. —With respect to carnal lust: <cit><quote lang="la">jamdudum gestit moecho hoc abdomen adimere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 5, 5</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">but opp. to lechery (libido): alius libidine insanit, alius abdomini servit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 7:26:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 7, 26, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abduco: <entryFree id="n55" type="main" key="abdu_co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-dūco</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n55.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v</hi>. <hi rend="ital">a</hi>. (ABDOVCIT =abduit, in the epitaph of Scipio, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 550</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">perf</hi>. abduxti, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 5, 2, 16</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">imper</hi>. abduce, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 108</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 5, 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 63</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">but also abduc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 86</bibl></cit>), <hi rend="ital">to lead one away, to take or bring with one, to carry off, take or bring away, remove,</hi> etc.</sense><sense id="n55.1" n="I" level="1"><usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n55.2" n="A" level="2">In gen., of personal objects; constr. <hi rend="ital">aliquem, ab, ex, de; in, ad</hi>: SVBIGIT. OMNE. LOVCANAM. OPSIDESQVE. ABDOVCIT (=subigit omnem Lucanam obsidesque abducit), epitaph of Scipio, 1. 1.: hominem P.
