cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">manus abstineant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor abstinendust (apstandust, R.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me ostreis et muraenis facile abstinebam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab alienis mentes, oculos, manus, de Or. 1, 43: manus animosque ab hoc scelere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se nullo dedecore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:11:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 11, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se cibo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:8:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 8, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ab obsidibus quidem iram belli hostis abstinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquos ab legatis violandis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se armis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 2 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence: <cit><quote lang="la">manum a se,</quote> <trans><tr>to abstain from suicide</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:37 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 37 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n242.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>: abstinere, <hi rend="ital">to abstain from</hi> a thing; constr. with <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quin</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quominus</hi>, the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n242.3" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud abstinent culpā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 2, 18</bibl></cit> Ritschl: <cit><quote lang="la">injuriā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:17:72" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 17, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabā (Pythagorei),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:58:119" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 58, 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proelio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:22:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 22, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:45:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 45, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatorio ambitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Hist. 2, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auribus principis,</quote> <trans><tr>to spare them</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ann. 13, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sermone Graeco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">publico abstinuit,</quote> <trans><tr>did not go out</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:36 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 36 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne a me quidem abstinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:43:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 43, 171</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut seditionibus abstineretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:10:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 10, 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:50:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 50, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n242.4" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ne a mulieribus quidem atque infantibus abstinerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:47:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 47, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n242.5" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum mi abstineant invidere,</quote> <trans><tr>if they only cease to envy me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:23" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n242.6" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">quin</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quominus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre abstinent, quin castra oppugnent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:45:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 45, 10</bibl></cit>: ut ne clarissimi quidem viri abstinuerint,<cb n="ABST" />  quominus et ipsi aliquid de eā scriberent, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 3</bibl>.—（* <foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (in Greek construction like the Greek <foreign lang="greek">a)pe/xesqai/ tinos</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">abstineto irarum calidaeque rixae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:27:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 27, 69</bibl></cit> (cf. infra, abstinens).—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">te scio facile abstinere posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tamen abstinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:534" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 534</bibl></cit>.—Esp. in med., <hi rend="ital">to abstain</hi> from food: <cit><quote lang="la">abstinere debet aeger,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 12, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">abstĭnens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">abstaining from</hi> (that which is unlawful), <hi rend="ital">abstinent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">temperate;</hi> constr <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> with <case>abl.</case>, or <usg type="style">poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">esse abstinentem, continere omnes cupiditates praeclarum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praetorem decet non solum manus, sed etiam oculos abstinentes habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:40:144" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 40, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impubi aut certe abstinentissime rebus venereis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:4:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus abstinens pecuniae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 37</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">alieni abstinentissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 8, 5</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">somni et vini sit abstinentissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:1:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, Auson. <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Act. 28</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, Col. and Plin. l. l.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">abstĭnenter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">unselfishly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:16:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 16, 37</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, Augustin. Mor. Manich. 2, 13.</sense></entryFree>
absto: <entryFree id="n243" type="hapax" key="absto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-sto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n243.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to stand off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at a distance from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stand aloof</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si longius abstes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:361" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 361</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abstractio: <entryFree id="n244" type="hapax" key="abstracti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abstractĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abstraho</etym>, <sense id="n244.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a separation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjugis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Dict. Cret.</author> 1, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abstractus: <entryFree id="n245" type="main" key="abstractus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abstractus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of</entryFree>
abstraho: <entryFree id="n246" type="main" key="abstra^ho"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abs-trăho</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (abstraxe = abstraxisse, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:650" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 650</bibl>), <sense id="n246.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to draw away from</hi> a place or person, <hi rend="ital">to drag</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pull away.</hi> </sense><sense id="n246.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n246.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut me a Glycerio miserum abstrahat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 8</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">liberos ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem de matris complexu avellere atque abstrahere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 21</bibl></cit> (17): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem e gremio e sinuque patriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:24:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 24, 59</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">for which, aliquem gremio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:658" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 658</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem raptim ex oculis hominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:49:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 49, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves e portu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:27:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 27, 6</bibl></cit> (al. a portu): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem a conspectu omnium in altum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:36:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 36, 145</bibl></cit> (corresp. with, a terra abripuit).—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">bona civium Romanorum diripiunt ... in servitutem abstrahunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:42:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 42, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem remulco abstraxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 23</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n246.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">to withdraw</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alienate from</hi> a party: <cit><quote lang="la">copias a Lepido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 18, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Germanicum suetis legionibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n246.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to draw away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">withdraw</hi>, <hi rend="ital">divert</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus se a corpore abstrahet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a rebus gerendis senectus abstrahit (for which in the preced., avocare),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me a nullius commodo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem a malis, non a bonis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">magnitudine pecuniae a bono honestoque in pravum abstractus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 29:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 29, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia in duas partes abstracta sunt, respublica, quae media fuerat, dilacerata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 41:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 41, 5</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">abstractus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a.;</hi> in the later philosophers and grammarians, <hi rend="ital">abstract</hi> (opp. concrete): <cit><quote lang="la">quantitas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Or. 2, 24, 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abstrudo: <entryFree id="n247" type="main" key="abstru_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abs-trūdo</orth>, <itype>ūsi, ūsum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n247.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to push</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thrust away</hi>, and hence <hi rend="ital">to conceal</hi> (cf. abdo). </sense><sense id="n247.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 6, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4, 5, 3</bibl>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 5, 2, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in cerebro colaphos,</quote> <trans><tr>to thrust into the brain itself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:3:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 3, 68</bibl></cit> (cf. a similar passage from Verg. under <hi rend="ital">abdo</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">mane me in silvam abstrusi densam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tectum inter et laquearia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 69</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n247.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">in profundo veritatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tristitiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 5</bibl></cit> al.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">abstrūsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">hidden</hi>, <hi rend="ital">concealed.</hi> </sense><sense id="n247.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: corpus abstrusum in flumine, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 308, 8</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 195 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">insidias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:Agr. 2:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. Agr. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:7:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 7, 147</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incendium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:130:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 130, 4</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">serpens abstrusa terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:129:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 129, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n247.4" n="2" level="3"> In <hi rend="ital">neutr. absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in abstruso esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be in concealment</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 129</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">to be unknown</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n247.5" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: dolor reconditus et penitus abstrusus, <hi rend="ital">a concealed and inwardly repressed sorrow</hi>, Auct. Or pro Dom. 10: <cit><quote lang="la">disputatio paulo abstrusior,</quote> <trans><tr>requiring a somewhat deeper investigation</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 10, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo abstrusus,</quote> <trans><tr>reserved</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 24</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> not used.— <hi rend="ital">Adv. comp.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">abstrūsĭus</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 28, 1, 49</bibl>: semet amandarunt, <hi rend="ital">more closely.</hi> <cb n="ABSU" /></sense></entryFree>
abstruo: <entryFree id="n248" type="spur" key="abstru^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-strŭo</orth>, a false read. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 27</bibl>.</entryFree>
abstruse: <entryFree id="n249" type="main" key="abstru_se_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abstrūsē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. abstrudo, <sense id="n249.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
abstrusio: <entryFree id="n250" type="hapax" key="abstru_si^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abstrūsĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abstrudo</etym>, <sense id="n250.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a removing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">concealing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">seminis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, p. 183</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abstrusus: <entryFree id="n251" type="main" key="abstru_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abstrūsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>abstrudo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
abstulo: <entryFree id="n252" type="hapax" key="abstu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">abs-tŭlo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, an old form (from which is the perf. abstuli), = aufero, <sense id="n252.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to take away</hi>: aulas abstulas, Plaut. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> P. 376</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
absuetudo: <entryFree id="n253" type="spur" key="absue_tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absuētūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, a false read. in <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 318</bibl> for assuetudo.</entryFree>
absum: <entryFree id="n254" type="main" key="absum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-sum</orth>, <itype>āfui</itype> (better than abfui), āfŭtūrus (aforem, afore), <pos>v. n.</pos>, in its most general signif., <sense id="n254.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be away from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be absent.</hi> </sense><sense id="n254.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n254.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> without designating the distance (opp. <hi rend="ital">adsum</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">num ab domo absum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me absente atque insciente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domini ubi absunt,</quote> <trans><tr>are not at home</tr>, <tr>not present</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 53</bibl></cit>: facile aerumnam ferre possum, si inde abest injuria, Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 430, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n254.3" n="B" level="2"> With reference to the distance in space or time; which is expressed either by a definite number, or, in gen., by the advs. <hi rend="ital">multum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">paulum</hi> (not <hi rend="ital">parum</hi>, v. below) <hi rend="ital">longe</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">edixit, ut ab urbe abesset milia pass. ducenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:12:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 12, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra, quae aberant bidui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic locus aequo fere spatio ab castris Ariovisti et Caesaris aberat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud longe abesse oportet,</quote> <trans><tr>he ought not to be far hence</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 166</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legiones magnum spatium aberant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">menses tres abest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud permultum a me aberit infortunium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 7</bibl>.—With the <hi rend="ital">simple abl.</hi> for ab: <cit><quote lang="la">paulumque cum ejus villa abessemus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 1</bibl></cit> Görenz; but, ab ejus villa, B. and K.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nuptā abesse tuā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 774</bibl></cit>.— With <hi rend="ital">inter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec longis inter se passibus absunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:907" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 907</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">prope</hi>, <hi rend="ital">propius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proxime</hi>, to denote a short distance: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc nobis prope abest exitium,</quote> <trans><tr>is not far from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 3, 8</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with est: prope est a te Deus, tecum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 41" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loca, quae a Brundisio propius absunt, quam tu, biduum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam abes propius,</quote> <trans><tr>since you are nearer</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">existat aliquid, quod ... absit longissime a vero,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 11, 36</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 13</bibl>; Caes. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:16 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 16 al.</bibl>—Hence the phrase: tantum abest, ut—ut, <hi rend="ital">so far from</hi> —<hi rend="ital">that</hi>, etc. (Zumpt, § <cit><quote lang="la">779), the origin of which is evident from the following examples from Cic. (the first two of which have been unjustly assailed): id tantum abest ab officio, ut nihil magis officio possit esse contrarium, Off. 1, 14 (with which comp. the person. expression: equidem tantum absum ab ista sententia, ut non modo non arbitrer ... sed, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:60:255" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 60, 255</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">tantum abest ab eo, ut malum mors sit, ut verear, ne, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:31:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 31, 76</bibl></cit>: ego vero istos tantum abest ut ornem, ut effici non possit, quin eos oderim, <hi rend="ital">so far am I from</hi>—<hi rend="ital">that</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 11, 14</bibl>; sometimes <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quoque</hi> is added to the second clause, Lentul. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 15, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:50" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 50</bibl>; more rarely <hi rend="ital">contra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:31:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 31, 4</bibl>. Sometimes the second <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> is left out: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum afuit, ut inflammares nostros animos: somnum isto loco vix tenebamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:80:278" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 80, 278</bibl></cit>; on the contrary, once in Cic. with a third <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>: tantum abest ut nostra miremur, ut usque eo difficiles ac morosi simus, ut nobis non satisfaciat ipse Demosthenes, Or. 29, 104.</sense><sense id="n254.4" n="II" level="1"> Hence, </sense><sense id="n254.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be away from</hi> any thing unpleasant, <hi rend="ital">to be freed</hi> or <hi rend="ital">free from</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a multis et magnis molestiis abes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a culpa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 20</bibl></cit>: a reprehensione temeritatis, Planc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 23</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n254.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be removed from</hi> a thing by will, inclination, etc.; <hi rend="ital">to be disinclined to</hi> (syn. <hi rend="ital">abhorreo</hi>)' a consilio fugiendi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab istis studiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ceteri a periculis aberant,</quote> <trans><tr>kept aloof from</tr>, <tr>avoided</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 6, 3</bibl></cit>. toto aberant bello, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 63</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n254.7" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be removed from a thing</hi> in regard to condition or quality, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be different from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to differ</hi> = abhorrere abest a tua virtute et fide, Brut. et Cass. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 2</bibl>: istae <foreign lang="greek">kolakei=ai</foreign> non longe absunt a scelere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec non absunt a consuetudine somniorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Divin. 1, 21</bibl></cit>, <pb n="13" /> <cb n="ABSU" /> 42.—Since improvement, as well as deterioration, may constitute the ground of difference, so absum may, according to its connection, designate the one or the other: <cit><quote lang="la">nullā re longius absumus a naturā ferarum,</quote> <trans><tr>in nothing are we more elevated above the nature of the brute</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:16:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 16, 50</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also the much-contested passage,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 7, 17</bibl></cit>: longissime Plancius a te afuit, i. e. valde, plurimis suffragiis, te vicit, <hi rend="ital">was far from you in the number of votes</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">had the majority;</hi> v. Wunder ad Planc. proleg. p. 83 sq.; on the other hand, <hi rend="ital">to be less</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inferior</hi>: longe te a pulchris abesse sensisti, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 339, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multum ab eis aberat L. Fufius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 62, 222</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:370" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 370</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n254.8" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Not to be suitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proper</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">fit for</hi> a thing: <cit><quote lang="la">quae absunt ab forensi contentione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:11:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 11, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab principis personā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ep. 1, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n254.9" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be wanting</hi>, = desum, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:11:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 11, 31</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 122 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">unum a praeturā tuā abest,</quote> <trans><tr>one thing is wanting to your praetorship</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 25</bibl></cit>: quaeris id quod habes; <cit><quote lang="la">quod abest non quaeris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 4, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:970" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 970</bibl> and 1095.—After Cicero, constr. in this signif. with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid huic abesse poterit de maximarum rerum scientiā?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:11:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 11, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abest enim historia litteris nostris,</quote> <trans><tr>history is yet wanting to our literature</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 5</bibl></cit>.—So esp. in the poets: <cit><quote lang="la">donec virenti canities abest morosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 9, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 24, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:371" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 371</bibl>.—Hence the phrase non multum (neque multum), paulum, non (haud) procul, minimum, nihil abest, quin. <hi rend="ital">not much</hi>, <hi rend="ital">little</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nothing is wanting that</hi> (Zumpt, Gr. § 540); but not parum, since <hi rend="ital">parum</hi> in good classical authors does not correspond in meaning with <hi rend="ital">non multum</hi>, but with <hi rend="ital">non satis</hi> (v. parum): <cit><quote lang="la">neque multum abesse ab eo, quin, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 2, 2</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque multum afuit quin,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:35:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 35, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paulumque afuit quin, ib. § 2: legatos nostros haud procul afuit quin violarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minimum afuit quin periret,</quote> <trans><tr>was within a little of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil afore credunt quin,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:147 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 147 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n254.10" n="F" level="1"> Abesse alicui or ab aliquo, <hi rend="ital">to be wanting to</hi> any one, <hi rend="ital">to be of no assistance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">service to</hi> (opp. adsum): <cit><quote lang="la">ut mirari Torquatus desinat, me, qui Antonio afuerim, Sullam defendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 5</bibl></cit>: facile etiam absentibus nobis (<hi rend="ital">without our aid</hi>) veritas se ipsa defendet, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 11, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">longe iis fraternum nomen populi Romani afuturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 36</bibl></cit>. So also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 5, 13</bibl>: et quo plus intererat, eo plus aberas a me, <hi rend="ital">the more I needed your assistance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the more you neglected me</hi>, v. Wunder ad h. l.; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 20 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense><sense id="n254.11" n="G" level="1"> Cicero uses abesse to designate his banishment from Rome (which he would never acknowledge as such): <cit><quote lang="la">qui nullā lege abessem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:34:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 34, 37</bibl></cit>; cf.: discessus. —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">absens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype> (<hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> regul. absentium; <cit><quote lang="la">absentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit>), <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">absent</hi> (opp. praesens). </sense><sense id="n254.12" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">vos et praesentem me curā levatis et absenti magna solatia dedistis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:3:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 3, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:33:121" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 33, 121</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quocirca (amici) et absentes adsunt et egentes abundant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:7:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut loquerer tecum absens, cum coram id non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me absente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illo absente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,006:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tull. 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 60</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">absente accusatore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 99</bibl></cit> al.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mente absentissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 4:4" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 4, 4</bibl></cit>.—Of things (not thus in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">Romae rus optas, absentem rusticus urbem tollis ad astra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 28</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Rhodus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rogus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:77:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 77, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:87" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imagines rerum absentium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:2:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">versus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n254.13" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n254.14" n="1" level="3"> In conversat. lang. </sense><sense id="n254.15" n="(a)" level="5"> Praesens absens, <hi rend="ital">in one's presence or absence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">postulo ut mihi tua domus te praesente absente pateat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:8:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 8, 29</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n254.16" n="(b)" level="5"> Absente nobis turbatumst, <hi rend="ital">in our absence</hi> (so also: <cit><quote lang="la">praesente nobis, v. praesens),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 3, 7</bibl></cit>; Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 76, 19</bibl> (Com. Rel. p. 165 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n254.17" n="2" level="3"> In polit. lang., <hi rend="ital">not appearing</hi> in public canvassings as a competitor: <cit><quote lang="la">deligere (Scipio) iterum consul absens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:42:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 42, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:22:9" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 22, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n254.18" n="3" level="3"> = mortuus, <hi rend="ital">deceased</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:prol. 20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. prol. 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7</bibl>, praef. § 8.—</sense><sense id="n254.19" n="4" level="3"> Ellipt.: absens in Lucanis, <hi rend="ital">absent<cb n="ABSY" />  in Lucania</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">absent and in Lucania</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 5, 3</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
absumedo: <entryFree id="n255" type="hapax" key="absu_me_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absūmēdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>absumo</etym>, <sense id="n255.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a consuming</hi> or <hi rend="ital">devouring consumption</hi>, in a pun: <cit><quote lang="la">quanta sumini absumedo!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 3, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
absumo: <entryFree id="n256" type="main" key="absu_mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-sūmo</orth>, <itype>mpsi, mptum</itype> (not msi, mtum), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n256.0" n="I" level="1"> Orig., <hi rend="ital">to take away;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">to diminish by taking away.</hi> Of things, <hi rend="ital">to consume</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to annihilate;</hi> of persons, orig. <hi rend="ital">to ruin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to corrupt;</hi> later, in a phys. sense, <hi rend="ital">to kill.</hi> Thus Hercules, in the transl. of the Trachiniae, complains: sic corpus clade horribili absumptum extabuit, <hi rend="ital">consumed</hi>, ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:8:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 8, 20</bibl>; so Philoctetes in a piece of Attius: jam jam absumor: conficit animam vis vulneris, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:7:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 7, 19</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 209 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">jam ista quidem absumpta res erit: diesque noctesque estur, bibitur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">absumpti sumus, pater tuus venit,</quote> <trans><tr>we are lost</tr>, <tr>undone!</tr></trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 5, 1, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi quid tibi in tete auxili est, absumptus es,</quote> <trans><tr>you are ruined</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum te fidelem facere ero voluisti, absumptu's paene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 4, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pytisando modo mihi quid vini absumpsit!</quote> <trans><tr>has consumed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 48</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">absumet heres Caecuba dignior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:14:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 14, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensas malis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:257" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 257</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:268" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3, 268</bibl>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">absumptis frugum alimentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:30:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 30, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbem flammis,</quote> <trans><tr>to consume</tr>, <tr>destroy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 7, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:130" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 130</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">plures fame quam ferro absumpti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:39:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 39, 14</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quos non oppresserat ignis, ferro absumpti,</quote> <trans><tr>killed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 6, 6</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">multi ibi mortales ferro ignique absumpti sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 7, 3</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">nisi mors eum absumpsisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 30 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">animam leto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:654" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 654</bibl></cit>.—Absumi, <hi rend="ital">to be killed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi nuper Epiri rex Alexander absumptus erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Absumi in aliquid, <hi rend="ital">to be used for any thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be changed into</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dentes in cornua absumi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:37:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n256.1" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to ruin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ille et curā et sumptu absumitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">satietatem amoris,</quote> <trans><tr>to consume</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 5, 6</bibl></cit>.—Often of time: <cit><quote lang="la">ne dicendo tempus absumam,</quote> <trans><tr>spend</tr>, <tr>pass</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 10</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">quattuor horas dicendo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:37:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 37, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:10:114" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 10, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">biduum inter cogitationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:6:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnam partem aetatis in hoc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
absumptio: <entryFree id="n257" type="hapax" key="absumpti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absumptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>absumo</etym>, <sense id="n257.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a consuming</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:7:5:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 7, 5, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
absumptus: <entryFree id="n258" type="main" key="absumptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absumptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of absumo.</entryFree>
absurde: <entryFree id="n259" type="main" key="absurde_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absurdē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. absurdus.</entryFree>
absurditas: <entryFree id="n260" type="hapax" key="absurdi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">absurdĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>absurdus</etym>, <sense id="n260.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dissonance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">incongruity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absurdity</hi>, (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> 3, 11</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Op. Min. 102</bibl> Lindemann.</sense></entryFree>
absurdus: <entryFree id="n261" type="main" key="absurdus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-surdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ab, <hi rend="ital">mis-</hi>, and Sanscr. svan = sonare; cf. susurrus, and <foreign lang="greek">su=rigc</foreign>, = a pipe; cf. also absonus</etym>, <sense id="n261.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">out of tune</hi>, hence <hi rend="ital">giving a disagreeable sound</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harsh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rough.</hi> </sense><sense id="n261.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox absona et absurda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:11:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 11, 41</bibl></cit>; so of the croaking of frogs: absurdoque sono fontes et stagna cietis, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:9:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 9, 15</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n261.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., of persons and things, <hi rend="ital">irrational</hi>, <hi rend="ital">incongruous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absurd</hi>, <hi rend="ital">silly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">senseless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stupid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio inepta atque absurda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc pravum, ineptum, absurdum atque alienum a vitā meā videtur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 8, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carmen cum ceteris rebus absurdum tum vero in illo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud quam incredibile, quam absurdum!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">absurda res est caveri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 37</bibl></cit>: bene dicere haud absurdum est, <hi rend="ital">is not inglorious</hi>, per litotem for, <hi rend="ital">is praiseworthy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glorious</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3</bibl> Kritz.—Homo absurdus, <hi rend="ital">a man who is fit</hi> or <hi rend="ital">good for nothing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin plane abhorrebit et erit absurdus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:20:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 20, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">absurdus ingenio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 62</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">sermo comis, nec absurdum ingenium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 13, 45</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:8:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 8, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 13</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 13</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">absurdē</orth>. </sense><sense id="n261.3" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">discordantly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">canere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:4:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 4, 12</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n261.4" n="2" level="3"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">irrationally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absurdly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 1, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:58:219 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 58, 219 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:8:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 8, 1, 4</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Trin. 4" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Trin. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
absyrtis: <entryFree id="n262" type="main" key="Absyrtis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Absyrtis</orth>, v. 2 Absyrtus.</entryFree>
absyrtus: <entryFree id="n263" type="main" key="Absyrtus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Absyrtus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/ayurtos</foreign>, <sense id="n263.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Æetes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Colchis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">killed by his sister Medea in her flight with Jason; he was torn</hi> <cb n="ABUN" /> <hi rend="ital">in pieces by her</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and his limbs were scattered in the way to prevent her father's pursuit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:9:6 sq" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 9, 6 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:19:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 19, 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n264" type="main" key="Absyrtus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Absyrtus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/ayurtos</foreign>, <sense id="n264.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Illyria which flows into the Adriatic Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:190" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 190</bibl> (al. <hi rend="ital">Absyrtis</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Apsyrtis</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
abtorqueo: <entryFree id="n265" type="spur" key="abtorque^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ab-torquĕo</orth>, a false read. ap. Att. instead of obtorqueo, Trag. Rel. p. 210 Rib.</entryFree>
abundans: <entryFree id="n266" type="main" key="a^bundans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbun-danter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>abundo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
abundantia: <entryFree id="n267" type="main" key="a^bundanti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundantĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abundo</etym>, <sense id="n267.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plenty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fulness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">richness</hi> (syn. copia). </sense><sense id="n267.1" n="I" level="1"> In the Cic. and Aug. per. usu. with a <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> to define it more exactly: <cit><quote lang="la">omnium rerum abundantia et copia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 97</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">otii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 9, 1</bibl></cit> al.—</sense><sense id="n267.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniary wealth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">riches</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 94</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">laborare abundantiā,</quote> <trans><tr>from overloading the stomach</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 44</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 40</bibl>).—Fig., of speech: <cit><quote lang="la">multa ex juvenili abundantiā coërcuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 1, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abundatio: <entryFree id="n268" type="hapax" key="a^bunda_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n268.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an overflowing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fossae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 16, 20, § 121</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abunde: <entryFree id="n269" type="main" key="a^bunde_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>as if from an obs. abundis, e</etym>, <sense id="n269.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in great profusion</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abundantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exceedingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">very;</hi> constr., </sense><sense id="n269.1" n="A" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi>: perfuse atque abunde usi magnum pondus auri, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 516, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde satis facere quaestioni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus mala abunde omnia erant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 21</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with esse (like satis, frustra, bene est, etc.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 58:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 58, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 63, 2</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi abunde est, si satis expressi, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>I am more than satisfied</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 30 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">abunde est, si,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 2</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sit satis abundeque, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:44:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 44, 7</bibl></cit>; and: abunde est, with <hi rend="ital">a subject-clause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc dixisse abunde est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:19:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 19, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:3:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:8:7 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 8, 7 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sufficere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:22:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 22, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contingere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cavere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:759" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 759</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">persequi aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:103:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 103, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde agnoscere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:116:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 116, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mirari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:16:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 16, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:116:3 al" default="NO">2, 116, 3 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n269.2" n="B" level="2"> With <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde magna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde pollens potensque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">par,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:29:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 29, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">constans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:17:13" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 17, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulchrum atque magnificum, Plin. H. N. praef. § 15: abunde similes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:25" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disertus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">elatus spiritus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:104 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 1, 104 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n269.3" n="C" level="2"> With <pos>adv.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde satis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 59</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">abunde dixit bene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:9:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 9, 7</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n269.4" n="D" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (like satis, affatim, etc.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Rudd. II. p. 317): terrorum et fraudis abunde est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:552" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 552</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potentiae gloriaeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:86" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 86</bibl></cit>: honorum, Front. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 177</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus abunde et ingenii et otii et verborum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:8:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 8, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
abundo: <entryFree id="n270" type="main" key="a^bundo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-undo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n270.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of a wave, <hi rend="ital">to flow</hi> over and <hi rend="ital">down</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to overflow</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">redundo</hi> signifies to flow over a thing with great abundance of water, to inundate): apud abundantem antiquam amnem, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 192, 4</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 175 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">flumina abundare ut facerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:267" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 267</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:282" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 282</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:484" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 484</bibl>; and in the beautiful figure in Plaut.: ripis superat mi atque abundat pectus laetitiā, <hi rend="ital">for joy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">my heart swells above its banks and overflows</hi>, Stich. 2, 1, 6: <cit><quote lang="la">ita abundavit Tiberis, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:38:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 38, 10</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quando aqua Albana abundāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:15:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 15, 11</bibl></cit>: so, <cit><quote lang="la">fons in omnem partem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 22, 51, § 188</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n270.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n270.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of plants, <hi rend="ital">to shoot up with great luxuriance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de terris abundant herbarum genera ac fruges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:920" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 920</bibl></cit> (in Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> 6, 3</bibl>, the better read. is <hi rend="ital">obundantes</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> p. 65</bibl> Vahl.).</sense><sense id="n270.3" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to abound</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be redundant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive deest naturae quippiam, sive abundat atque affluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:29:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 29, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abundabant et praemia et operae vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:H. N. 14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> H. N. 14</bibl></cit>, prooem. § 4.—Once with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenuioribus magis sanguis, plenioribus magis caro abundat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n270.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To overflow with any thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to have an abundance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">superabundance of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to abound in</hi> (the most usual signif.); constr. with <case>abl.</case>, and once <usg type="style">poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (cf. Rudd. II. p. 189 n.). </sense><sense id="n270.5" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">villa abundat porco, haedo, agno, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 16, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeceptis philosophiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenio, otio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier abundat audaciā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 84</bibl></cit>: cujus oratio omnibus <pb n="14" /> <cb n="ABUT" /> ornamentis abundavit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">equitatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna copiā frumenti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquā, Auct. B. Alex. 1: et aequalium familiaritatibus et consuetudine propinquorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clientibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 26</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: amore abundas, <hi rend="ital">you are too fortunate in love</hi> (successu prospero affluis, Don.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 3, 11</bibl>; cf. Lucil.: ille abundans cum septem incolumis pinnis redit, ap. Don. Ter. l. c.—</sense><sense id="n270.6" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: quarum et abundemus rerum et quarum indigeamus, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 498, 7</bibl>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">to abound in wealth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be rich</hi> (cf. abundantia, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">et absentes adsunt et egentes abundant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:7:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caietam, si quando abundare coepero, ornabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 4, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbun-dans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">overflowing.</hi> </sense><sense id="n270.7" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of rivers, fluids, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">fluvius abundantior aestate,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>fuller</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:227" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 103, 106, § 227</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abundantissimus amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">menses (mulierum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 71, § 147</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n270.8" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n270.9" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Existing in abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abundant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adesā jam, sed abundanti etiam pecuniā sic dissolutus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 12, 40</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n270.10" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Containing abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abounding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi>, <hi rend="ital">full;</hi> constr. with <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n270.11" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir abundans bellicis laudibus, Cn. Pompeius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:22:78" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 22, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abundantior consilio, ingenio, sapientiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:26:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 26, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rerum copiā et sententiarum varietate abundantissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:14:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 14, 58</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n270.12" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(via) copiosa omniumque rerum abundans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 8, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corporis, Claud. ap. Eutrop. 2, 380: pietatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 113</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n270.13" n="(g)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">non erat abundans, non inops tamen oratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:67:238" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 67, 238</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abundantior atque ultra quam oportet fusa materia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:4:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abundantissima cena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:42" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 42</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 17</bibl>.—Also in a bad sense, of discourse, <hi rend="ital">pleonastic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">superabundant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:56" default="NO">8, 3, 56</bibl>.— <itype>Hence</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex abundanti,</quote> <trans><tr>superabundantly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:5:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 5, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:6:2" default="NO">5, 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:33:7:12:section=46 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 33, 7, 12, § 46 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n270.14" n="b" level="4"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">abounding in wealth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi> (syn. dives, opp. egens): <cit><quote lang="la">(supellex) non illa quidem luxuriosi hominis, sed tamen abundantis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:27:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 27, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec utrum abundantis an egentis signa sunt?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:1:section=43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 1, § 43</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundanter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">abundantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copiously</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">loqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferre fructum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:9:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 9, 42</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Trop. 10</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:74" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 74</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abundus: <entryFree id="n271" type="main" key="a^bundus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>abunde, Hand, Turs. I. p. 71</etym>, <sense id="n271.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">copious</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">lavacris nitidis et abundis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:2:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aqua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> 734</bibl></cit> Murat.</sense></entryFree>
abusio: <entryFree id="n272" type="main" key="a^bu_si^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbūsĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>abutor</etym>. <sense id="n272.0" n="I" level="1"> In rhet. lang., <hi rend="ital">a harsh use of tropes</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">kata/xrhsis</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 33, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:27:94" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 27, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:2:5" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 2, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">per abusionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:3:9 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 3, 9 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n272.1" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">abuse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">misuse</hi> (eccl. Lat.).</sense></entryFree>
abusive: <entryFree id="n273" type="main" key="a^bu_si_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbūsīvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>abusivus</etym>. <sense id="n273.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">By an improper use</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:35" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:35" default="NO">9, 2, 35</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n273.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Slightly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not in good earnest</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 24, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abusivus: <entryFree id="n274" type="main" key="a^bu_si_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbūsīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>abutor</etym>, <sense id="n274.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">misapplied</hi>: appellatio, Auct. Pan. ad Const. 4.</sense></entryFree>
abusor: <entryFree id="n275" type="main" key="a^bu_sor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbūsor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n275.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">he who misuses</hi> (eccl. Lat.).</sense></entryFree>
abusque: <entryFree id="n276" type="main" key="a^busque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-usque</orth>, <pos>prep.</pos> (vox Vergil.), <sense id="n276.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">even from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as far as from</hi>, like ab constr. with <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">Siculo prospexit abusque Pachyno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:289" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 289</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animalia maris Oceano abusque petiverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 37</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 311 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 19, 4 al.</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 97</bibl>, the correct read. is usque).</sense></entryFree>
abusus: <entryFree id="n277" type="main" key="a^bu_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbūsus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>abutor</etym>, <sense id="n277.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a using up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consuming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wasting</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:7:5:5 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 7, 5, 5 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
abutor: <entryFree id="n278" type="main" key="a^bu_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăb-ūtor</orth>, <itype>ūsus, 3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n278.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to use up</hi> any thing, <hi rend="ital">to use to the end</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to consume entirely</hi> (utendo vel in usum consumere, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 76, 29</bibl>); constr. in ante-class. period with <case>acc.</case>, in class. per. with <case>abl.</case> </sense><sense id="n278.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n278.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos aurum abusos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 126</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">argentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 2, 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui abusus sum tantam rem patriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">operam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:prol. 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. prol. 5</bibl></cit> Ruhnk.: <cit><quote lang="la">meretricem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suam vim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1032" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1032</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n278.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">sumus parati abuti tecum hoc otio,</quote> <trans><tr>to spend this leisure time with you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 9</bibl></cit> Creuz; so, <cit><quote lang="la">otio liberaliter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:105:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 105, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni tempore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:9:section=25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 9, § 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sole,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 6, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me abusum isto prooemio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:6:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 6, 4 al.</bibl></cit>: abuti <cb n="ACAD" /> aliquā re ad aliquid, <hi rend="ital">to make use of for any purpose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take advantage of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abuti sagacitate canum ad utilitatem nostram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:60:151" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 60, 151</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 6</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n278.4" n="II" level="1"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">to misuse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to abuse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sapientiam tuam abusa est haec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 29</bibl></cit>; so in the exordium of the first oration against Cat.: Quousque tandem abutere, Catilina, patientia nostra? <hi rend="ital">will you abuse our patience?</hi> libertate, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:43:section=113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 43, § 113</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">intemperanter otio et litteris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iis festivitatibus insolentius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:52:176 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 52, 176 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legibus ac majestate ad quaestum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:19:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 19, 54</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:25:section=61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 25, § 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:23:64 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 23, 64 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n278.5" n="B" level="2"> Esp., in rhet. (of words), <hi rend="ital">to use improperly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:27:94" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 27, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:43:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 43, 169</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:6 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 6 al.</bibl>!*? <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abusa,</quote> <trans><tr>consumed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 44</bibl></cit>; so also Varr.: utile utamur potius quam ab rege abutamur, ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 792</bibl> P., and Q. Hortensius, ib., abusis locis: <cit><quote lang="la">abutendus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
